The Taxpayer Advisory Service (TAS)  is an independent organization within the IRS that helps taxpayers resolve difficulties arising from their appeal to the IRS, offers administrative and legislative advice to prevent or remedy problems, and protects the rights of taxpayers. We strive to ensure that every taxpayer is treated fairly and that you know and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights. We represent your interests before the IRS.

If you are a sole proprietor or your company is registered as a partnership or an S corporation, you can view your tax information not only by opening a company tax account but also by opening a business account.

This chapter lists the business taxes you may need to pay and the forms you may need to file. It also discusses taxpayer identification numbers (TINs, according to the English acronym). Table 1-1 lists the benefits of electronic filing of a tax return. Table 1-2 lists the federal taxes you may need to pay, the deadlines for payment and the forms for reporting such taxes. Table 1-3 contains check sheets listing the forms and applications you typically need to file when closing a business.

The Social Security Number is generally used as a taxpayer identification number. It is required on all personal income tax forms, such as Form 1040 and its appendices. To apply for a Social Security Number, use Form SS-5  Application for a Social Security Number. The form can be obtained from any Social Security Administration (SSA) office or by calling 800-772-1213 or from the Social Security Administration website at SSA.gov/froms/uk/uk/uk-5 (English).

The IRS issues an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number to foreign nationals temporarily or permanently residing in the United States who do not have a Social Security Number and are not eligible for it. The Individual Taxpayer Identification Number will expire each time the taxpayer fails to file a federal tax return (or for each taxpayer who is not reported as a dependent on another taxpayer's tax return) for 3 consecutive years.

If you must have a taxpayer identification number, enter it along with your Social Security number in Schedule C, as instructed. There are several ways to apply for an EIN: Online at Employer ID Numbers (EINs)  (Employer ID Number) at IRS.gov/businesses/small.gov; if your principal place of business is in the United States or in a U.S. territory, you will receive an Employer ID number immediately after processing the information in your application, by calling 267-941-1099 (calling is charged); only if your principal place of business is outside the United States or U.S. territories, or by mail or fax: Form SS-4 Application for an Employer ID Number.

If you have employees, you must get the Social Security number of each of them. You must write down the name and Social Security number of each employee as it is written on their Social Security cards. If the employee's name is written incorrectly on the card, he must apply to the Social Security Administration for a new card. This may be the case if the employee has changed his last name after marriage or divorce. Each employee must complete a Form W-4 "Certificate of Withholding from Wage and Salary" to withhold the correct amount of federal income tax from his wages. If your employee does not have such a Social Security number, the employee must file a Form SS-5 with the Social Security Administration.

If you make payments to a person who is not your employee and you must report such payments on the information return, you need to know the social security number of that person. If you have to report payments to some organization, such as a corporation or a partnership, you need to know the employer identification number of that organization. To obtain the social security number or the employer identification number of the recipient of the payment, use Form W-9 Request for Taxpayer Identification Number and Certification. If the recipient of the payment does not provide his or her identification number, additional withholding may be charged.

You may file your income tax return using Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR and attaching Schedule C. Enter the net profit or loss specified in Schedule C in Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Use Schedule C to calculate your net profit or loss from your business. If you have operated more than one company as a sole proprietor, you must attach a separate copy of Schedule C for each company.

If you file electronically using tax preparation software or a tax preparation professional, you will need to sign your tax return using the self-selecting PIN (personal identification number) method for the IRS e-file program. If you are married and file a joint tax return, both you and your spouse will need to create your own PIN and enter it as an electronic signature. To create the PIN, you must know your adjusted gross income (AGI) as it appears on your original tax return for the year 2023 (indicate the amount of money you received by mail, or by tax preparation specialist), you will need to sign the tax return using the self-selecting PIN (personal identification number) method for the IRS e-file program.
You can get a refund by mail or by direct transfer to your current or savings account. Using the IRS e-file system, you can get your refund twice as fast as filing a paper tax return.

As with paper tax returns, if you owe taxes, such as federal taxes, state taxes, student loans, or alimony, you (or, if you file a joint return, your spouse) may not get the full refund. You will be notified if the tax refund you applied for is included in the debt. You may file a spousal claim using Form 8379  Payment to the Injured Spouse or Form 8857  Application for Unmarried Spouse Exemption from Taxes, Interest, and Fines to partially or fully recover the joint refund transferred to your spouse's individual liabilities.

The IRS will issue refunds for tax returns filed for earned income tax credits or child tax credits no earlier than mid-February 2025, not just for the portion of the refund that relates to those tax credits, but for the entire amount.

If your tax return shows a tax debt, you must pay it by the filing deadline (regardless of whether there is an extension) to avoid penalties and interest for late payment. The debt for the calendar year 2024 must be paid by April 15, 2025. You can pay by various means, including a scheduled electronic debit from a current or savings account, a debit or credit card.
You will need to complete Form 8879 Right to Sign Tax Reports Electronically to the IRS to give the tax professional permission to enter your chosen PIN into the tax return.

IRS has developed electronic versions of tax forms that can also be filed in electronic format for free. Free File electronic forms are the best solution for those who prepare their tax return on their own. There are no restrictions on the amount of income they can use. The Free File electronic forms allow basic calculations. Only federal tax forms are available.

If you file for a fiscal year (see explanation in Chapter 2), you must file the tax return by the 15th day of the fourth month following the end of your fiscal year. If you fail to file the tax return on time, you may incur penalties and interest. If you cannot file the tax return on time, please use Form 4868 Application for Automatic Extension of the Term of a U.S. Individual Income Tax Return  to request an automatic extension of the term of the tax return for a period of 6 months. If you file a tax return for a calendar year using this form, you may extend the term until October 15.

You pay federal income tax on your current income. You must pay income tax on your income or salary during the year. As a rule, income tax is withheld from your salary for employees. If the tax is not withheld from your salary or if the amount is not enough, you may have to pay a tax deduction.

Generally, you must pay an estimated tax if you plan to owe taxes, including self-employment tax (see below), up to $1,000 on your tax return. Use Form 1040-ES to calculate and pay this tax. If you do not have to pay an estimated tax, you may pay any tax debt on your tax return.

If you have not paid enough income tax and self-employment tax in 2024, or if you have not paid enough estimated tax, you may be fined for the amount you have not paid. In this case, the IRS will calculate the amount of the fine and send you an invoice. You may also use Form 2210 "U.S. Taxpayer's Default in Estimated Tax by Individuals, Estates, and Trusts" to check for the amount of the fine and calculate the amount of the fine.

Self-employment tax is a tax on Social Security and Medicare, mostly levied on self-employed individuals. It is similar to Social Security and Medicare taxes, which are withheld from the wages of most employees. If you earn income as a full-time employee, you do not have to pay self-employment tax on that income.

If you are a taxpayer in the United States, you must have received one credit card card for every $1,730 ($1,810 in 2025) of taxable income to the Social Security Administration in 2024, so if you received $6,920 in taxable income (self-employment and wages) to the Social Security Administration in 2024, you will receive four credits ($6,920 ÷ $1,730).

If you file a tax return or report changes in your self-employment income after the deadline, the Social Security Office will only accept a claim for cancellation or reduction of your income. The Social Security Office will not change your self-employment income to increase it.
The self-employment tax rate on net income is 15.3% (12.4% is Social Security tax plus 2.9% is Medicare tax).

In 2024, only the first $168,600 that combines wages, tips, and net earnings is subject to any combination of Social Security tax as part of the self-employment tax at 12.4%, Social Security tax or Level 1 tax as part of the railroad employee pension fund. In 2024, the full amount of your wages, tips, and net earnings is subject to any combination of Medicare tax as part of the self-employment income tax at 2.9%, Medicare tax as part of the Medicare tax, or Medicare tax as part of the railroad employee pension benefits tax. However, if the wages and tips that you receive as a self-employed worker are subject to the Social Security tax at 12.4%, Social Security tax as part of the railroad employee tax, or Level 1 tax as part of the railroad employee pension fund, you must pay the Social Security tax at 12.9%, or Level 2 tax as part of the railroad employee tax, or Level 1 tax as part of the railroad employee pension fund, or Level 2 tax as part of the Medicare tax, or Level 2 tax as part of the railroad employee pension fund, or Level 2 tax as part of the self-employed worker tax, or Level 2 tax as part of the railroad employee social security tax, or Level 1 tax as part of the railroad employee pension fund, or Level 2 tax, or Level 3 tax as part of the railroad employee tax, or Level 2 tax, or Level 3 tax as part of the railroad employee tax, or Level 2 tax, or Level 3 tax, or Level 2 tax as part of the railroad employee tax, or Level 3 tax, or Level 2 tax, or Level 3 tax, or Level 2 tax, or Level 3 tax, or Level 2 tax, or Level 3 tax, or Level 2 tax, or Level 3 tax, or Level 2 tax, or Level 3 tax, or Level 2 tax, or Level 3 tax, or Level 4 or Level 3 tax, or Level 2 tax, or Level 3 tax, or Level 3 tax, or Level 4 or Level 2 tax, or Level 3 tax, or Level 3 tax, or Level 4 or Level 3 or Level 4 or Level 5 tax, or Level 3 or Level 5 tax, or Level 5 tax, or Level 2, or Level 2, or Level 2, or Level 3 or Level

If you receive income from both wages and self-employment, the limit on the amount of Medicare tax you can pay on self-employment income is reduced by the amount of your wages that are taxable to Medicare (but not less than zero).

For more information, see Publication 15 (Circular E)  Tax Guide for Employers. This publication lists your tax obligations as an employer. Do not reduce the amount of deductions for taxes paid to Social Security and Medicare by the amount of the non-refundable and refundable portions of the deductions for eligible hospital and family leave expenses received under the FFCRA (The Families First Coronavirus Relief Act) and the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 and shown on your employer's tax return. Instead, list these deductions as income. To determine whether the individuals in your company are your employees, see Publication 15A. To determine whether the individuals in your company are your employees, see Publication 15A. In the publication of the independent living tax benefit, you may be required to deduct the amount of the deductions for the employee's earnings as a self-employed person, as a contractor or as an independent worker. If you are an independent contractor, you may be required to deduct the amount of the deductions for the employee's earnings as a self-employed person, or as a self-employed person.
(') For more information on excise duties, see the Publication No 510 on excise duties.

The federal excise tax, which must be reported on Form 720 Quarterly Federal Excise Tax Return, includes several categories of taxes, including the following: Environmental protection tax on the sale or use of ozone-depleting substances and imported products containing or produced with such substances; communications and air transportation tax; fuel tax; first retail sale tax on heavy duty cars, trailers and tractors; manufacturer's tax on the sale or use of a number of different goods; artificial sunlight tax; and service tax on the manufacture of artificial sunscreens.

The use of certain types of heavy trucks, trucks, and buses on public roads is subject to federal excise tax. This tax applies to vehicles whose gross taxable weight is 55,000 pounds (25,000 kg.) or more. This tax must be reported on Form 2290  Tax Return for the Use of Heavy Road Vehicles. For more information, see the instruction manual for Form 2290.

If you make or receive payments as part of an economic activity, you may be required to report them to the IRS on a tax return. To check that payments are part of your income, the IRS will compare the payments listed on the tax return with each individual's income tax return. You must provide a copy of each tax return you are required to file with the recipient or payer.
Regardless of the amount of the payment, you must also file Form 1099-NEC for each person from whom you withheld any federal income tax (report in box 4) under the Supplemental Withholding Rules.

The law imposes fines for failure to file the following forms: Form 1099-MISC, Form 1099-NEC or Form W-2. Fines are also imposed for providing incorrect information. See the general instructions for some information declarations for additional information. Failure to file an information declaration. Failure to file an information declaration by the deadline, failure to include all necessary information or incorrect information is punishable by a fine. Failure to provide correct reports to the payee. Failure to submit the required report to the payee by the deadline, failure to include all necessary information or incorrect information is punishable by a fine.

If you can prove that the violation was committed for a reasonable reason and not due to negligence, you will be exempt from fines. Furthermore, for not including all the necessary information or for entering incorrect information in a de minimis (minor) number of information returns when correcting errors until 1 August of the year in which the returns are required, the fine will not be imposed. (De minimis - 10 returns is half or 1% of the total number of returns (whichever is greater) that you need to submit for the year in question.)

You must file Form 8300 Report of Cash Payments Received by a Business or Company in an Amount of Over $10,000  if you received more than $10,000 in cash in one cash transaction or in two or more commercial transactions. Cash payments made in U.S. and foreign currency are also reported. Some money market instruments are also reported, such as checks signed by bank tellers, traveler's checks, and postal transfers. This list does not include checks issued to a personal account of an individual (a cheque in cash). For more information, see Publication No. 1544 Report of Cash Payments Received in an Amount of Over $10,000.
You must calculate your taxable income and file a tax return for the previous annual reporting period, called the tax year.
If you do not have a taxable tax year, you choose the tax year by filing the first tax return for that tax year.

If you filed your first tax return for a calendar tax year and later start your business as an individual entrepreneur, you must continue to use the tax year unless you have the permission of the IRS to change it or you are not allowed to change it without the permission of the IRS. For more information, see the section 'Changes in tax year' below. If you have chosen a calendar tax year, you must keep accounting books and reports and report your income and expenses for the period from 1 January to 31 December of each year.

The fiscal year is the 12th consecutive month ending on the last day of any month except December. The 52-53-week fiscal year is the fiscal year that varies from 52 to 53 weeks, but does not necessarily end on the last day of the month. If you choose a fiscal year, you must keep accounting records and report your income and expenses using the same tax year. For more information about the fiscal year, including the 52-53-week tax year, see Publication No. 538.
You must use the same accounting method for calculating your taxable income and keeping your accounting records, and you must use an accounting method that clearly shows your income.

Some taxpayers may assume that they have IRS permission to change their accounting method. Permission is granted for the tax year for which the taxpayer requests the change (the year of change) if the taxpayer complies with the provisions of the automatic change procedure. For an application filed under the automatic change procedure, which is generally described in the Tax Code 2015-13, 2015-5 I.R.B. 419 (or any later version), and which is available at IRS.gov/IRB/2015-05_IRB#RP-2015-13, no fee is required.

You can keep accounts for your business and personal income and expenses using a variety of accounting methods, for example, you can calculate your business income by the accrual method, even if you use the cash method for calculating your personal income and expenses.

If you have two or more separate and distinct lines of business, you can use different accounting methods for each one, as long as that method clearly reflects the income of each line of business. e are only separate and distinct if you keep complete and distinct records and records for each line of business.
In the cash method, you must include in your gross income all the income items that you actually or conditionally receive during the tax year.

You have implied income when the amount is credited to your account or given to you without limitation. you don't have to own it. if you appoint someone as your agent, it's assumed that you received income when your agent received it.
If you receive income in this way, you will receive income on the cancellation or payment of the debt.For more information, see the section 'Debt paid' in the section 'Types of income' in Chapter 5.

If you include a certain amount in your income and you need to pay it back in full or in part the next year, you can generally deduct the amount of the refund in the year you made it. If the amount you paid back is more than $3,000, a special rule applies. For details on the special rule, see "Refund Payments" in Chapter 8 of Publication No. 17.
The purpose of accrual accounting is to compare the income and expenses of the year in question.The accrual method is based on the following principles:

When using the accrual method, you normally include the amount in your gross income for the tax year in which all events determining your eligibility for income occurred, and you can determine this amount with reasonable accuracy.For a taxpayer with a proper financial statement or other financial statement prepared in accordance with the regulations of the Ministry of Finance, the test of "all events" for the gross income item is considered to have been completed no later than when it is included in the proper financial statement or other similar financial statement.
If you include a reasonable estimate in gross income and later find that the exact amount is different, take into account the difference in the tax year in which you determine the amount.

If you provide services at the base rate specified in the contract, you must charge income at the base rate, even if you agree to receive payments at a lower rate, until you complete the services and then receive the difference.

You can also claim an advance payment for a tax year that is not yet due, but you can claim an advance payment for a tax year that is not yet due, or you can claim an advance payment for a tax year that is not yet due, but you can claim an advance payment for a tax year that is not yet due.

When the production, purchase or sale of goods is a revenue-generating factor in your business, you should generally keep inventory accounts at the beginning and end of the tax year, unless you are a small business taxpayer. When you keep inventory accounts, you should use the accrual method to account for sales and purchases.

You cannot deduct business expenses and interest owed to a dependent who uses the cash method of accounting until you make a payment and the corresponding amount is included in the dependent's gross income. Determine the degree of kinship for this rule at the end of the tax year in which the expenses or interest would otherwise be subject to deduction. If the deduction is not allowed under this rule, the rule will continue to apply even if your relationship with this person ends before the expenses or interest are included in that person's gross income. The dependents include your family members, including brothers and sisters (half or half sisters), your spouse's ancestors, and direct descendants. For lists of other dependent persons, see section 267 of the tax code.

If you are a small business owner, you may not include inventory in your assets, but you should still use a method of accounting for inventory that clearly reflects income. If you choose not to include inventory in your assets, it will not be an indication of an inability to clearly reflect income if your accounting method treats LMS (material inventory) as inventory or as inventory or if it is consistent with your method of financial accounting for inventory. However, if you choose to include inventory in your assets, you should generally use the accrual method and estimate inventory each year to determine the value of the goods sold in the first year.

You are considered a small business owner if you (a) have an average annual gross income of $30 million or less for the previous 3 tax years and (b) are not a tax haven (as defined in section 448 (d) (3)). If your business did not exist during the entire three-year tax period used to calculate the average gross income, calculate the average for the period it existed, and if your business has a predecessor, include the predecessor's gross income for the 3 year tax period when calculating the average gross income tax.

You must estimate your MCI at the beginning and end of each tax year to determine the value of the goods sold (Appendix C, line 42). To determine the value of your MCI, you need a method of identifying the items of income and expense in your MCI and a method of estimating those items. What are the rules for estimating your MCI?
