What are the generally accepted accounting principles for accounting for similar types of business and what are the reasons for which you should clearly reflect your income. Your inventory methods should be used regularly from year to year.

You may be covered by the Uniform Capital Asset Taxation Rules if you are engaged in any of the following activities, except when the property is for personal use, not for business or activity carried on for profit: the production of immovable or tangible personal property. In this context, tangible personal property includes a film, sound recording, videotape, book, or similar property. the acquisition of immovable property for resale.
There are special methods of accounting for certain items of income or expense, including the following: amortization of intangible assets, as discussed in Chapter 7 of Publication No. 225.

The sale of a commercial enterprise is not usually a sale of a single asset. Instead, all of the assets of the enterprise are sold. Typically, in this case, each asset is treated as sold separately for determining profit or loss. The buyer and seller involved in the sale of a commercial enterprise must report to the IRS on the distribution of the sale price among the assets of the enterprise. The taxable income of the enterprise is not less than the net income of the enterprise.

The sale price of the property is defined as the total amount of money you received plus the fair market value of all the property or services you received.The sale price also includes all of your liabilities to the buyer and all of your liabilities in respect of the property you transferred, such as property taxes or mortgage payments.

The fair market value of a property is defined as the price at which it is transferred from the seller to the buyer, provided that both parties are not coerced and are reasonably aware of all the relevant facts.

Your income or loss from the disposal of property is generally recognized income or recognized loss for tax purposes. Recognized income must be included in gross income. Recognized losses may be deducted from gross income. However, in some cases, income or loss from certain transactions involving the exchange of property is not recognized. See the section "Tax-exempt transactions" above.

If you have gained or lost money from the sale of a capital asset, you must determine whether it is a short-term or a long-term gain or loss. The gain or loss is classified as short-term or long-term depending on how long you owned the asset before disposing of it. The period during which you owned the asset before disposing of it is called the tenure.
You may also need to file Form 4797 and Appendix D (Form 1040).

This is the initial cost of a new qualified fixed-rate or fixed-contribution pension plan (including a 401k plan), SIMPLE plan or SEP plan. For more information, see Publication No. 560 Pension Plans for Small Companies.

This non-refundable tax credit is due to small businesses that bear the costs of providing physical access for disabled people. e.g. In order for your business to comply with the provisions of the Disability Act 1990, you must bear the costs. e.g. For more information, see Form 8826.
This deduction relates to qualified railway maintenance expenses paid or incurred during the tax year.

This chapter explains what business income is, how it is treated for tax purposes, and what income is not considered income. It also provides guidance for people engaged in certain activities. If there is a connection between your business and the income you receive, then this income is considered business income. A connection exists if it is obvious that the income would not be received if you did not own the business. You may have business income even if you do not take part in the activities of your business on a regular basis.

If you are a self-employed person, you must have a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, a job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job, job,

Name, Image, Likeness or NIL is a term describing the means by which student-athletes are allowed to receive financial compensation. NIL can be classified as self-employment income. If your income from NIL exceeds $600 from any source, including non-cash income, you will receive a Form 1099-NEC or Form 1099-MISC, containing the amount of income you must report on your tax return.

If you are self-employed, you may receive a Form 1099-K showing the total dollar amount of all reportable payments. This may not be the amount you should report as income, as it may not include all income, but it may include items that are not included in your income (such as sales tax).
The income you listed on Schedule C may be qualified income from sole proprietorship and entitle you to a deduction on Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR (line 13).

In your tax return, you must report any income you receive from your business, including income not listed on Form 1099, filed by the taxpayer, except where the law allows it to be excluded. In most cases, self-employment income comes in the form of cash, checks, and credit card payments. However, self-employment income may come in other forms, including property or services. These and other types of income are explained below.

If you are a real estate agent who receives income from renting property, or a hotel, motel, etc. owner who provides certain services to guests (housekeeping, etc.), you must indicate your rental income and expenses in Appendix C. If you are not a real estate agent or an entrepreneur as described in the previous sentence, indicate your rental income and expenses in Appendix E. For details, see Publication No. 527 'Rental Property'.

You are a real estate agent if you sell property to clients for profit.The rent you pay for the property you hold for sale to clients is subject to SE tax.However, the rent you pay for the property you hold for speculative purposes or as an investment is not subject to SE tax.

The rental income from a trailer park is subject to SE tax if you are a self-employed owner of a trailer park, renting out premises and parking spaces, and providing essential services to residents for their convenience. It is usually considered that you provide essential services to residents if they are intended primarily for the convenience of the residents and are not usually provided to maintain the plots in a state suitable for living. The services are considered to be essential if the remuneration for them constitutes a significant part of the rent payments of the residents. Examples of services that are not usually provided for the convenience of the residents are the supervision and maintenance of the recreation hall provided by the park, the dispatch of the monthly resident newsletter, the work of the suburban carriage of goods and services provided to residents for their convenience, the purchase of a new car, the purchase of a new car, the purchase of a new car, the purchase of a new car, the purchase of a new car, the purchase of a new car, or the maintenance of a new car.

The income from renting a hotel, a boarding house or an apartment building is subject to SE tax if you provide services to residents. It is generally considered that you provide services to residents if these services are intended primarily for their convenience and are not services normally provided when renting rooms for residential use only. An example of services that are not normally provided for the convenience of residents is maid service. However, heating and lighting, cleaning stairs and hallways, and garbage collection are services normally provided for the convenience of residents.

If you are engaged in the rental of personal property (equipment, vehicles, official clothing, etc.), include the amount of rent you receive in your gross income in Appendix C. Prepaid rent and other payments described in the item 'Rental of immovable property' above may also be received for the rental of personal property. If you receive any of these payments, include them in your gross income as explained above.

If during the tax year the loan that is due becomes unrecoverable and you use the accrual method, you should generally include in gross income the specified interest that is unconditionally payable and accrued before the loan became unrecoverable. If the accrued interest previously included in income subsequently turns out to be unrecoverable, you may be able to claim a deduction for unrecoverable debts. See the section "Unsurable debts" in Chapter 8.

If the sale is in installments and charges little or no interest, you may have to treat part of each payment as undeclared interest income. See the Unstated Interest and Original Issue Discount (OID) sections of Publication No. 537.

Dividends are in principle the business income of securities dealers. For most sole proprietors and legal employees, however, dividends are not business income. If you have shares as a personal investment not related to your business activity, then dividends on shares are not business income. If you receive dividends on business insurance premiums that you deducted from the taxable base in one of the previous years, you must declare these dividends in full or in part as business income in your tax return. To find out what amount you must declare, see the section  Recovering previously deducted expenses in the section  Other types of income below.

Generally, if your debt is cancelled or forgiven, except when it is done as a gift or inheritance, you must include the amount written off in your gross income for tax purposes.If the debt is related to business activity, the amount of the written off debt is shown in line 6 of Schedule C.If the debt is not related to business activity, the written off amount is shown in line 8c of Schedule 1 (Form 1040).
You have not realized the income from the cancelled debt if the amount of the debt could be deducted from the tax base.

Qualified Real Property Business Indebtedness includes refinancing of debt described in paragraph (3) above, but only to the extent that it does not exceed the debt being refinanced. If you are the owner of an entity without a legal entity (such as a one-member LLC), see the section on Qualified Real Property Business Indebtedness in Chapter 1 of Publication No. 4681 to see if you are eligible for this exclusion. It is not permitted to exclude from income an amount in excess of any of the following two items: 1. an excess (if any): 1. an increase in the principal amount of the qualified real property business in debt that is not exceeding the principal amount of the debt that is being refinanced; 2. a reduction in the amount of the principal amount of the qualified real property business in debt that is being refinanced immediately prior to the cancellation of the debt (such as a one-member LLC); or 2. a reduction in the amount of the principal amount of the debt that is being cancelled immediately before the cancellation of the debt (such as a reduction in the amount of the principal amount of the debt that is being cancelled) due to the company; or 2. a reduction in the amount of the principal amount of the principal amount of the debt that is being cancelled immediately before the cancellation of the debt (such as a reduction in the amount of the principal amount of the principal amount of the debt) due to the property that is immediately before the cancellation of the property property; or a reduction in the amount of the principal amount of the property that is immediately before the property that is immediately before the property; or is immediately before the cancellation of the property that is immediately before the property; or is the property that is immediately before the property that is cancellation of the property;
If you have already filed a tax return without making a choice, you can still do so by filing a tax return with amendments within 6 months of the expiry of the tax year (excluding extensions).

Restricted property is property that is subject to certain restrictions that affect its value. If you received a package of securities or other restricted property in payment for your services, the fair market value of such property in excess of the value of your services is included in the income shown in Schedule C after the restriction is removed. However, you may pay tax in the year you received the property. Further information on the inclusion of restricted property in income is given in Publication No. 525  Taxable Income and Tax Exempt Income.
This rule does not apply to depreciation. depreciation is calculated according to the rules explained below.
The depreciation deduction must be repaid to the State in the following situations.

If the degree of use of the register property (described in the 'Depreciation' section of Chapter 8) for business purposes has decreased to 50% or less in the tax year following the tax year in which you put the property into use, you may have to return part of the depreciation deduction. In this case, you include in the income declared in Schedule C part of the depreciation deduction for previous years. To calculate the amount to be declared in Schedule C, use Part IV of Form 4797 'Sale of company property' to determine the amount to be included in Schedule C. For more information, see the section 'What are the criteria for business use?' in Chapter 5 of this Publication No. 946.

If you deduct the value of an asset under Section 179 (described in the "Amortization" section of Chapter 8) and the extent to which it is used for business purposes before the end of the payback period falls to 50% or less, you will be required to return part of the deduction under Section 179.
If you have sold or exchanged depreciable property for a profit, you must report all or part of the depreciation gain as ordinary income.

Any deductions you receive from your income are declared as part of income in Schedule C. However, deductions should not be included in income if you legally deduct them as a deduction from the relevant expense item, as capital expenditure or as the value of goods sold.

If you have been reimbursed for a bad debt or any other amount that you have already deducted from your taxable income in a previous year, you must include the amount of this reimbursement in income in Schedule C. However, if the total or partial amount of the deduction in previous years did not reduce your tax liability, you are entitled to deduct from your income the amount that did not affect your tax liability. If you have deducted from your income a portion of the amount of the refund, you must attach to your tax return a calculation showing how the deduction was calculated.
The increase in the value of your property is not declared as income until you sell it or dispose of it in another taxable way.

If the tenant builds new buildings or improvements to your property, the increase in value due to the improvements is not your income, but if the facts show that the improvements are included in your rent, the increase in value is declared as income.

The right of ownership remains with the commissionaire, i.e. you, even after the commissioner takes possession of the goods. Thus, if the goods are sent for sale on consignment terms, you cannot declare either income or loss until the commissioner sells the goods. The goods shipped on consignment terms remain in your inventory until they are sold. The goods you received on consignment terms should not be included in your inventory. Include in your income the commission income or commission for the sale of the goods transferred to you on consignment terms when you are the seller or the recipient of the goods, or the commission income or loss depends on the accounting method you use to calculate the amount of the accounting loss.

A short-term lease is a contract (or other agreement to live or use) for a term of 15 years or less. When determining whether a lease is for 15 years or less, the following rules apply. When determining whether a lease is for 15 years or less, consider whether it provides for the possibility of renewal. However, no provision should be made regarding the possibility of renewal at the fair market rate determined at the time of renewal. Two or more leases in the same transaction (or series of interrelated transactions) in respect of the same or substantially similar commercial space are considered to be a single contract.

You must declare this income regardless of whether it is declared to you in the information declaration or not. You are engaged in direct sales if you meet all of the following requirements: 1. You are engaged in one of the following professional or business activities. 1. You sell or solicit the sale of consumer goods either at home or at another place that is not a permanent retail establishment, or to any buyer on a buy-sell basis or on a deposit-fee basis for resale at home or at another place that is not a permanent retail establishment. 2. You deliver or distribute newspapers or store advertising materials (including any services directly related to the profession or business field). 2. You are engaged in virtually any amount of payment (whether it is paid in cash or not) between an employee and you, and excluding any services provided for the purpose of selling them, on a cash basis, and you are not required to pay federal income tax on the amount of your income, excluding the amount of hours you have worked for them, and the amount of your income, and the amount of your income, and the amount of your income.

If you are an options or commodities dealer, your income and losses from dealing in or trading in contracts under section 1256 (regulated futures, foreign exchange contracts, stock options, options on other financial instruments and securities futures contracts) or in any other property associated with those contracts (for example, a stock option contract for hedging options) are set out in Appendix C. Further information is set out in sections 1256 and 1402 (i)).

You are a securities or commodities trader if you engage in transactions to buy and sell securities or commodities for your own account. As a securities or commodities trader (including if you have elected to re-appraise to fair market value under section 475 (f) as a securities or commodities trader), the income and losses from your transactions are not shown in Appendix C. For more information on securities or commodities traders, see Publication No. 550  Investment Income and Expenditure and Issue No. 429  Stock Market Makers.

You have not provided any services to the company after the termination of the contract and until the end of the year in which you received the payments. You have undertaken not to compete with the company for at least 1 year from the date of termination of your service contract. The total amount of payments depends mainly on the insurance policies you sold or charged to your account during the last year of your service agreement, or on the extent to which these policies remain in force for any length of time after the termination of your service agreement with the company. The type of service you provided depends on the type of service, the type of service you provided, the type of service you provided, the type of service you provided, the type of service you provided, the type of service you provided, and the type of service you provided.

The income paid by the insurance company to a retired non-employee insurance agent as a percentage of the commission he received before retirement is shown in Appendix C. The renewal commission and the deferred commission for the sale of policies before retirement are usually also shown in Appendix C. However, the renewal commission paid to the surviving spouse of the insurance agent is not shown in Appendix C.

This section discusses some of the most common differences that can affect your business transactions. Calculate your business income for the tax year based on your accounting method (see Chapter 2). If selling products is a profitable aspect of your business, you will generally need to declare your inventory to clearly show your income. Real estate agents are not allowed to include inventory. Further information about inventory is given in Chapter 2.
You must pay tax on all income you earn, and you cannot avoid paying tax by writing it off to a third party.

If the buyer of your property puts all or part of the purchase price into an escrow account, no part of that amount can be counted towards the gross sales until you receive it as actual or anticipated income, but when the contract and the escrow account agreement expire, the amount put into that account will become taxable income, even if you take possession of the assets no earlier than the following year.

There are two methods of accounting for immediate payment discounts. You can either credit them to a separate discount account or deduct them from the total amount of purchases for the year. Whichever method you use, you should be consistent. If you want to change your method of calculating inventory costs, you should file Form 3115. For more information, see the section Changing the Accounting Method in Chapter 2. If you credit these discounts to a separate account, you should include this credit balance in your business income at the end of the tax year. If you use this method, you will not deduct the same amount of the cost of the goods you purchased when you pay the immediate discount.

If you are taking goods for personal or family use, you must deduct this value from the total amount of goods you have purchased for sale. This is done by crediting to the purchase or sales account the value of the goods you have taken out for personal use. You must also credit this amount to your current account. The current account is a separate account you must keep for the income from business activities that you take out to pay for personal and family expenses. Likewise, as mentioned above, you also use it to account for the withdrawal of goods for personal or family use. This account is also known as the money withdrawal account or personal account.

The direct labour cost is the wage you pay to employees who work full time directly on the product you produce. p These costs also include the part of the wage you pay to employees who work directly on the product part time if you can determine that part of their wage.

The indirect labour costs are the wages you pay to employees performing general factory functions that have no direct or indirect connection to the production of a commodity product, but are a necessary part of the production process.

The overhead costs include such things as rent, heating, lighting, electricity, insurance, depreciation, taxes, maintenance, labor and oversight. e overhead costs that you attribute to direct and necessary production costs are included in the cost of goods sold.
When you subtract the year-end inventory from the cost of goods available for sale, the balance is the cost of goods sold for the tax year.

Once you have calculated the gross income from your business (Chapter 5) and the cost of goods sold (Chapter 6), you are ready to calculate the gross profit. You must determine the gross profit before you can deduct any expenses for running the business.

To calculate gross profit, first determine net revenue. Calculate net revenue (line 3) in Appendix C by subtracting any returns and discounts (line 2) from gross revenue (line 1). Returns and discounts include cash or credit returns you make to customers, discounts, and other additions to the actual selling price. Then subtract the cost of goods sold (line 4) from net revenue (line 3). The amount you receive  is the gross profit of your business activity.

You don't need to calculate the cost of goods sold unless the sale of goods is a factor in your business's income. Your gross profit is equal to net revenue (gross revenue minus refunds, discounts or other discounts). Most professions and companies that sell services rather than goods can calculate gross profit directly from net revenue this way.
This illustration of the "Gross profit" section of a retail company's income statement shows how gross profit is calculated.

At the end of each workday, make sure that your records match the actual cash and credit receipts for the day. You may find it helpful to use cash registers to keep track of receipts. You should also use a proper billing system and keep a separate bank account for your business.

If you collect state sales tax or local sales tax from a buyer as a seller of goods or services, you must include the amount you receive in your gross receipts. If you are required to collect state and local taxes from a buyer and remit them to the appropriate state or local government, you will not generally include these amounts in your income.

If you are a retailer or wholesaler, you can check the accuracy of the gross profit indicator. First, divide the gross profit by the net revenue. The percentage you get measures the average spread between the cost of goods sold and the selling price. Then compare that percentage to your policy on the price of goods sold. A small difference between these two percentages, or the absence of one, indicates that the gross profit indicator is accurate. A large difference between these percentages may indicate that you have miscalculated sales, purchases, inventory, or other items of cost. You should determine the cause of the difference.

You are a retailer. On average, you set the selling price so that you get a gross profit of 331/3% on sales. Net revenue (gross revenue minus returns and discounts) shown on your income statement is $300,000. Cost of goods sold is $200,000. Your gross profit is $100,000. To check the accuracy of your results this year, divide gross profit ($100,000) by net revenue ($300,000). The resulting value of 331/3% confirms your 331/3% interest rate.

If your company has income from a source other than ordinary business activities, enter this income in line 6 of Schedule C and add it to gross profit. The result is gross business income. Examples include income from interest calculation accounts, income from the sale of scrap metal, income from certain tax benefits and fuel tax refunds, and amounts reimbursed for bad debts.

You can deduct business expenses. These are called business expenses. These are expenses that you do not have to capitalize or include in the cost of goods sold, but can deduct in the current year. To get a deduction, business expenses must be both normal and necessary. Ordinary expenses  are expenses that are normal and accepted for your business. Necessary expenses  are expenses that are constructive and relevant to your business. An expense does not have to be indispensable to be considered necessary. For more information on the general rules for deducing business expenses, see Section 162 and its regulations. If you have expenses that are partly business related and not partly personal, you may not be able to deduct them. If you have a personal business, you may not be able to deduct them.

You can deduct contributions you make for your employees in Schedule C, Line 19. If you are an individual entrepreneur, you can deduct contributions you make for yourself in Schedule 1 (Form 1040) in Line 16. You can also deduct the fees of guardians if contributions to the plan do not cover them. Contributions are usually not taxed until you or your employees receive payments from the plan. You can also claim a tax credit if you are considering a new qualified plan with defined payments or defined contributions (including a small 401k plan), or a SIMPLE plan. See the SEIRA's instructions for employees' contributions to the plan. These contributions are usually tax deductible up to the amount of the earnings you have contributed to the plan.

Rent is any amount you pay for the use of property that you do not own. As a rule, you can only deduct rent as an expense for running a business if the rent is charged for the property that you use in your business. If you own or will own a share in the property or a right to the property, you cannot deduct rent.

You cannot get a deduction for rent for an unjustified lease. As a rule, the question of eligibility arises only if you and the tenant are related. A rent paid to a relative is eligibility if it is equal to the amount you would pay to a third party for the use of the same property. A rent is not eligibility only because it is calculated as a percentage of gross income. Relatives include members of your immediate family, including brothers and sisters (whether or not full-blooded), your spouse, ancestors and direct descendants.
If you rent your house and use part of it as a place of business, you can deduct the rent you pay for that part.You must not meet the requirements for commercial use of the house.

If you pay rent in advance, you can deduct only the amount that relates to your use of the rented property during the tax year.You can deduct the rest of the payment only during the period to which it relates.

You can deduct state gross income tax (as opposed to net income) directly related to your business activity on Schedule C. You can deduct other local income taxes as well as state income tax on Schedule A (Form 1040) if you specify itemized deductions. Federal income tax is not deducted.

You can deduct Social Security, Medicare, and Federal Unemployment Tax (FUTA) payments you made from your own funds as an employer.The taxes your employer withholds from the wages of employees are briefly explained in Chapter 1.You can also deduct payments you made as an employer to your state unemployment fund or state disability fund.You can deduct these payments as taxes.
You can deduct half of the self-employment tax in line 15 of Annex I (Form 1040). Self-employment tax is explained in Chapter 1 and Chapter 10 .

You can deduct from the tax on personal property any tax imposed by the local or state authorities on the use of personal property for business purposes, and you can deduct from the tax on the right to use property in the state or local area.

You can deduct in Schedule C the property taxes you pay on your business property. The property taxes deductible are any local or foreign taxes, as well as state property taxes, levied for the public welfare. The taxing authority must charge these taxes equally at the same rate on all property under its jurisdiction, and the proceeds must be used for the general purposes of the state or county.

Any sales tax that you pay for a service or for the purchase or use of a property is part of the cost of the service or property. If the service, cost, or use of the property is a deductible business expense, you can deduct the tax as part of that service or expense. If the property is a good purchased for resale, the sales tax is part of the value of the good. If the property is depreciable, add the sales tax to the base to calculate the depreciation. For information on the base of the property, see Publication No. 551. Do not deduct local taxes and state sales taxes imposed on the buyer, which you must collect and remit to the local or state government. These taxes are not included in the gross sales or sales tax.
You can deduct all excise duties which are normal and necessary expenses for running a business from Annex C. Excise duties are briefly explained in Chapter 1.

The tax office is usually your usual place of work, regardless of where your family home is located.It includes the whole town or district where your company is located.For more information, see Publication No. 463.
If, after the examination of the business premises, your home cannot be identified as your principal place of business, you cannot deduct the costs of the home office.

However, if you choose to take advantage of the de minimis benefit for tangible property, you may deduct the de minimis amounts paid for the acquisition or production of certain tangible property if those amounts are deducted by you for financial accounting or accounting purposes. If you have a corresponding financial statement, you may use this safe harbor to deduct amounts paid for tangible property up to US$5,000 per unit of goods or invoice. If you do not have an applicable financial statement, you may use the de minimis safe harbor to deduct amounts paid for the acquisition or production of certain tangible property, if those amounts are deducted by you for financial accounting or accounting purposes. If you do not have a valid financial statement, you may use the de minimis amount to deduct the amounts paid for the acquisition or production of certain tangible property, unless you have a qualifying criterion of US$500 per unit of goods or invoice. If you are not in possession of a valid account, you may use the de minimis amount to deduct the amounts paid for the acquisition or production of certain tangible property, unless you have a qualifying criterion of US$500 per unit of goods or invoice.
For more information on the choice and requirements for using the safe harbour rule for this material property, see the section on Regulating Material Property.

You may be eligible for deductions for the following expenses: advertising, bank commissions, donations to nonprofit organizations, education expenses, disability-related expenses, interviewing expenses, licensing and regulatory fees, moving equipment, employment assistance services for those who are laid off, penalties and fines for failure to perform or violate a contract, repair and maintenance of real or personal property, income reimbursement, utilities, and other services.

As a rule, you cannot deduct the following expenses as business expenses: kickbacks and kickbacks; charitable contributions; demolition or loss expenses; contributions to business, social, sports, dining, sports, aviation, and hotel clubs; entertainment expenses; improvements to real or tangible personal property; improvements  are amounts paid for the improvement, restoration, or work that adapts your property to a new or different use; lobbying expenses; penalties and fines that you pay to a government agency or authority because you broke the law; personal, household, and family expenses; political contributions; or payments related to sexual agreements or settlements; or such expenses may not be deducted if they are related to domestic violence or sexual abuse; or such payments may not be deducted if they are related to attorney fees or settlement costs.

If someone owes you money that you cannot get back, you have incurred a bad debt. There are two types of bad debt: business and non-business. Bad debts related to business activities are usually incurred as a result of professional or commercial activities. You can deduct bad debts as an expense on your tax return.

The debt is considered to be closely related to your business activity if the main motive for its origination was the business activity. The bad debts in the business activity are mainly the result of sales to customers on credit. They can also be the result of loans to suppliers, customers, employees or distributors. Goods and services that customers have not paid for are reflected in your books as receivables or receivables. If you cannot recover any part of this receivable, then the bad part is a bad debt. You can only receive a deduction for bad debts on these accounts and receivables if the amount of the debt was included in your gross income, either for the year when the deduction was declared or for the previous year.

If you have shown a deduction for a bad debt on your tax return and later collect that debt in whole or in part, you may have to include all or part of the amount received in gross income. You must include in your income exactly as much as you actually deducted. However, you may exclude from your income the amount deducted that did not reduce your tax.
For further information on business debts, see Section 166 of the Tax Code and its regulations.
If you use the accrual method, you usually report income when you earn it.You can get a bad debt deduction for bad debts if you include bad debts in your income.

If you use the cash method of accounting, you usually report your income when you receive your payment, but you cannot claim the deduction for bad debts against your debts if you have not received them and cannot receive them if you have never included them in your income.

Losses from company debts received by inheritance are classified the same as the debt received when the company was purchased. The death warrant classifies any loss from debts as an entrepreneurial bad debt if the debts were closely related to the professional or commercial activities of the deceased when they became worthless. Otherwise, the death warrant classifies the loss from such debts as a non-entrepreneurial bad debt.
If your business partnership is dissolved and one of your former partners becomes insolvent, you may have to pay more than your proportionate share of the partnership's debts.

You may deduct certain bad debts that become partially uncollectible during the tax year. Your tax deduction is limited to the amount you write off in your books during the year. You do not need to write off and deduct partially worthless debts annually. You may defer writing off until a later year. However, you cannot deduct any portion of the debt after the year when it becomes completely worthless. Two rules of debt write-off need to be considered: Substantially altered debt. An exception to the write-off rule exists for debt that has been substantially altered and in respect of which the creditor has shown profit on the tax return. For more information, see the regulations in Section 1.166 (a) to (a) (3).

If the debt becomes completely worthless in the current tax year, you can deduct the entire amount except for any amount deducted in the previous tax year when the debt was only partially worthless. You are not required to actually write off the accounts in order to show in the tax return a deduction of the hopeless debt for a completely worthless debt, but you should do so. If you do not do this and then the IRS decides that the debt is only partially worthless, you will not be able to deduct the debt for the tax year in question, because the deduction of the partially hopeless debt is limited to the amount actually written off. See the "Partially worthless debts" section above.

(i) Local business expenses do not include expenses you incur during overnight commutes from home. (ii) These expenses are deductible as business travel expenses and are explained in the Travel and Meals section. (iii) However, if you use your car during overnight commutes from home, use the rules in this section to calculate your car expenses. (vii) The tax home is your permanent place of business, regardless of where your family home is located. (vii) It includes the entire city or district where you work or conduct business. (vii) If you are a resident of a tax-free area, you are entitled to a tax-free deduction for your business expenses.
For local transportation or overnight trips by car or truck, you can generally use one of the following costing methods:

You can use the standard mileage rate to calculate the deductible for operating your car, van, pickup truck, or panel truck for business purposes.In the year 2024, the standard mileage rate for each mile driven for business purposes is 67 cents.If you choose to use the standard mileage rate for a year, you will not be able to deduct your actual expenses for that year, except for parking and road taxes related to your business.

If the property you acquire for use in business is going to be used for more than one year, you generally cannot deduct the entire value as business expenses in the year you acquire it. You must allocate the expenses over more than 1 tax year and deduct a portion of it each year on Schedule C. This method of deducting the value of the property for business is called depreciation.

As a general rule, you don't depreciate the cost of repairs or maintenance if they don't improve your property. Instead, you deduct these amounts on line 21 of Schedule C. Improvements  are the amounts paid for improving your property, restoring your property, or doing work that adapts your property for a new or different use.

Use Form 4562 "Contributions and Depreciation" if you are declaring one of the following: Depreciation of property put into service in the current tax year; Deduction under Section 179; Depreciation of any listed property (regardless of when it was put into service); Depreciation of property in the current tax year; Depreciation of property in the current tax year; Depreciation of property in the current tax year; Depreciation of property in the current tax year; Depreciation of property in the current tax year; Depreciation of property in the current tax year; Depreciation of property in the current tax year; Depreciation of property in the current tax year; Depreciation of property in the current tax year; Depreciation of property in the current tax year; Depreciation of property in the current tax year; Depreciation of property in the current tax year; Depreciation of property in the current tax year; Depreciation of property in the current tax year; Depreciation of property in the current tax year.

You cannot deduct insurance premiums on the following types of insurance: 1. Self-insurance reserve funds. You cannot deduct amounts credited to a reserve created for self-insurance. This applies even if you cannot obtain insurance coverage for certain business risks. However, your actual losses may be deducted. For more information, see Publication No. 547. 2. Loss of earnings. You cannot deduct insurance premiums on a policy that pays for your lost earnings due to illness or disability. However, see item 8 in the previous business list. 3. Certain types of life insurance and annuities. 1. Under contracts concluded before 9 June 1997, you cannot deduct the interest on a life insurance policy that you have written for a business owner. 4. You may also be prohibited from taking out a loan or indirect interest on any business loan if you are a policyholder or have a financial policy that is not included in your business's life insurance policy, or if you are a direct beneficiary of a life insurance policy, or if you are a financial policyholder, or if you are a non-financial policyholder, or if you are a financial policyholder, or if you are a non-financial policyholder, or if you are a financial policyholder, or if you are a non-financial policyholder, or if you are a non-financial policyholder, or if you are a non-financial policyholder, or if you are a non-financial policyholder, or if you are a non-financial policyholder, or if you are a non-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-financial-finan

Use Form 8962 and its separate instructions, and Publication 974, if the insurance plan you have created or are deemed to have created in your business is obtained through the health insurance marketplace and you claim a deduction from your insurance premiums.

For tax purposes, an alien is a person who is not a U.S. citizen. Aliens can be classified as temporary residents (non-resident aliens) and permanent residents (resident aliens). This publication will help you determine your status and give you the information you need to file a tax return in the United States. Alien residents are generally taxed on aggregate income worldwide, just as U.S. citizens are. Alien non-residents are taxed only on income from sources in the United States and on certain income related to professional or commercial activities in the United States.

The United States has suspended the operation of subparagraph (g) of paragraph 1 of Article 3 of the Convention. The remaining articles of the treaty will remain in force. The suspension entered into force on December 17, 2024 and will end on December 31, 2026 or, in the event that the governments of both countries adopt a corresponding decision, earlier. The partial suspension of the Convention on income tax with Russia. On June 17, 2024, the United States officially notified the Russian Federation of the partial suspension of the tax agreement between the two countries on the avoidance of double taxation with the USSR in the part concerning Belarus. The United States has suspended the operation of subparagraph (g) of paragraph 1 of Article 3 of the Convention as a resident disabled person until August 16, 2024. The law will not be in effect until August 23, 2024.

A nonresident alien (and some resident aliens) from a country with which the United States has a double taxation treaty may qualify for certain benefits.Most treaties require that the nonresident alien be a resident of the treaty country in order to receive the benefit in the year it is requested.However, in the case of some students, interns, faculty, or academics, some treaties require that the nonresident alien be a resident of the treaty country immediately prior to coming to the United States.

You can view the tables of double taxation agreements by going to IRS.gov/TreatyTables (English). You can read the recently signed U.S. double taxation agreements, protocols and tax information exchange agreements (TIEA) and their accompanying technical explanations from the Treasury Department as they become publicly available, as well as the Model Double Taxation Convention at Home.Treasury.gov/Policy-Issues/Tax-Policy/International-Tax (English). Please note that the documents of the agreements and TIEA are posted on this site after signature and before ratification and entry into force..The full text of the individual double taxation agreements can also be found at IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Tax-Agreements/United States-Businesses/International-States-Agreements/International-Tax-Agreements/United States-Tax-Agreements/United States-Tax-Agreements/United States-Tax-Agreements/United States-Tax-Agreements/United-States-International-Tax-Agreements/United-Agreements/United-States-Agreements/United-States-Agreements/United-States-Agreements/United-States-Agreements/United-Agreements/United-States-Agreements/United-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-Agreements-

Agreement income  is gross income of a non-resident alien that is not taxed under the relevant tax treaty. To determine the income items that are taxed at reduced rates under the tax treaties, calculate the income tax under each individual income item at the reduced rate that applies to the item under the tax treaty. To calculate this for non-agreement income tax, calculate either a flat rate of 30% or a flat rate of 30% depending on the tax treaty, but do not include the amount of income tax liability that would be deducted as income tax under the tax treaty, unless your income tax liability is actually related to your business activities, or if your income tax liability is not included in the U.S. income tax liability, then your income tax liability is not deducted as income tax under the tax treaty, but is included in the U.S. income tax liability, regardless of whether it is actually related to your business activities, or whether it is not taxed as income tax.

The terms of the benefits vary by specific tax treaty. For more information on the terms of a specific tax treaty, see the texts of most U.S. tax treaties at IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Businesses/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z. Technical explanations for many of these treaties can be found at the same site. See also Publication No. 901 (English).

Some double taxation agreements contain an "independent personal services" clause that allows residents of the treaty country to exempt income earned as an independent contractor or self-employed person from U.S. tax if such person is in the U.S. for a period not exceeding a certain number of days and if they do not have a fixed base of income regularly available to them in the U.S.

All treaties contain provisions for exemption from income taxes on income received by certain employees of foreign governments. However, there is variation in who is eligible for this benefit, depending on the particular treaty. Under many treaties, foreign nationals who are U.S. residents are not eligible for this benefit. Under most treaties, foreign nationals who are not citizens or subjects of a foreign state are not eligible for this benefit. Foreign government employees should read the relevant treaty carefully to understand whether they are eligible for the benefits.
Foreign residents may qualify for the double taxation treaty benefits in the situations described below.

Some exceptions to such a clause apply to all resident aliens (e.g., under the U.S.-People's Republic of China Agreement); others apply only to resident aliens who are not lawful permanent residents of the U.S. (i.e., ring-card holders). In certain cases, you do not need to specify income on Form 1040 or WSR-240 because the agreement retains the right to tax its citizens and residents as if the tax agreement had not entered into force. However, many tax agreements have exceptions to the clause that may allow a resident alien to continue to claim benefits under the agreement.

However, if you entered the United States as a nonresident alien but are now a nonresident alien for U.S. tax purposes, the tax exemption under the tax treaty will continue to apply if you provide a tax treaty (tax agreement) waiver for U.S. education and maintenance, scholarships, grants and research grants, and wages or other rewards for personal services. Once you become a nonresident alien, you generally can no longer claim tax exemption under the treaty for this income. However, if you entered the United States as a nonresident alien but are now a nonresident alien for U.S. tax purposes, the tax exemption under the treaty will continue to apply if you provide a tax treaty waiver (tax agreement) waiver for scholarships, grants and research grants, and wages or other rewards for personal services.

In some cases, you do not need to report income on Form 1040 or 1040-SR because the agreement does not tax that income in the U.S. However, if the income was listed as taxable income on Form W-2, Form 1042-S, Form 1099 or another information return, you should report it on the appropriate line of Form 1040 or 1040-SR (for example, line 1a, the amounts shown in column 1 of Form W-2). Enter the amount for which the benefits under the agreement are claimed in Appendix 1 (Form 1040), line 8z.

If you claim benefits under an agreement that repeals or amends any provision of the Tax Code and as a result of claiming those benefits your tax is reduced or may be reduced, you must attach a properly completed Form 8833 to your tax return.

You are not required to file Form 8833 in any of the following situations: 1. You claim a tax rate reduction under an agreement for interest, dividend, rent, royalties, or other fixed or determinable annual or periodic income normally taxed at the rate of 25% of the taxable income of the owner of an 8833 agreement. 2. You claim that the agreement reduces or modifies the taxation of income from personal dependent services, pensions, annuities, social security and other public pensions, or income of entertainers, athletes, students, interns, or teachers. The taxable income includes taxable scholarships and scholarship grants. 3. You claim a tax rate reduction or change in income under an international social security agreement or diplomatic or consular agreement. 4. You are a beneficiary of an agreement for a partnership or other fixed or determinable annual or periodic income normally taxed at the rate of 25% of the taxable income of the owner of an 8833 agreement. 6. You claim that the agreement reduces or modifies the taxation of income from personal dependent services, pensions, annuities, social security and other public pensions, or income of entertainers, students, interns, or teachers.

Employees of international organizations may exempt their wages from income tax under a provision, if any, in an international agreement establishing an international organization, or by meeting the requirements for obtaining a U.S. income tax exemption for such wages under U.S. tax law. International organization  is an organization designated by the President of the United States by executive order to receive the privileges, exemptions, and immunities provided by the International Organizations Immunities Act. The exemption contemplated in this chapter applies only to remuneration received for official services rendered to a foreign government or international organization. Other income from U.S. sources considered to have been received by persons eligible for this exemption may be fully taxed or have a favorable treatment under the agreement, regardless of whether such income is taxed in the form of dividends, whether it is published in the U.S. Treasury or not.

You should first review the exemption provisions under the Vienna Conventions or bilateral consular convention, if any, to determine whether your salary is subject to U.S. income tax exemption under those provisions.As a general rule, you are not eligible for the income tax exemption under the Vienna Convention or bilateral consular convention if you are a U.S. citizen or resident alien.For more information regarding the Vienna Conventions and bilateral consular conventions, please contact the Department of State's Office of Foreign Missions at FEMAOssistants@state.gov.uk.

If you are not covered by the Vienna Convention or the bilateral consular convention, but are a citizen of a country that has a double taxation treaty with the United States, you should review that treaty to see if it contains a provision exempting your wages from U.S. income tax. If you are a U.S. citizen or a resident alien working in the United States for a foreign government, your wages are not normally exempt from tax.

Employees of foreign governments who are not subject to the tax exemption provisions of any of the Vienna Conventions, the Bilateral Consular Convention, or the Double Taxation Avoidance Agreement may be exempt from U.S. income tax if they meet the following requirements to be eligible for the tax exemption on such wages under U.S. tax law. The tax exemption under U.S. tax law applies only to current employees of foreign government agencies, but not to former employees. Pensions received by former employees of foreign governments residing in the U.S. are not subject to the exemption under consideration here. This exemption does not apply to independent contractors. To determine whether you are an employee or an independent contractor, the following rules apply to your general income tax exemption on such wages under U.S. tax law. The exemption applies only to current employees of foreign government agencies, but not to former employees. Pensions received by former employees of foreign governments residing in the U.S. are not subject to the exemption under consideration here. This exemption does not apply to independent contractors. To determine whether you are an employee or an independent contractor, the following rules apply to your general income tax exemption on such wages under U.S. tax law.

If the international agreement establishing the international organization for which you are employed does not contain a tax exemption provision, and you are not a U.S. citizen (or if you are a U.S. citizen but also a citizen of the Republic of the Philippines), you may exempt your wages from tax under U.S. law. However, see the subsection "Aliens retaining immigrant (lawful permanent resident) status" below for a specific rule that may affect your eligibility for this exemption. The exemption from tax under U.S. tax law applies only to current employees of international organizations, but not to former employees.

If you sign a waiver under Section 247 (b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (USCIS Form I-508) to maintain your lawful permanent resident status (green card), you are no longer eligible for tax exemption under U.S. tax law from the date of filing the waiver. e If you are a foreign government employee or an international organization with a green card, to qualify for tax exemption under U.S. tax law, you must also demonstrate by means of a written statement from USCIS that you did not sign and file a USCIS Form I-508.
If you are an alien, you are in category (1) or (2) above, and you have applied for an exemption under section 247 (b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, you must obtain a departure permit.

Foreign nationals in any of these categories who have not filed an income tax return or paid income tax for any tax year must file a tax return and pay income tax before they are issued a departure permit on Form 2063.The departure permit on Form 2063 may be used for any departure during the current year.However, the IRS may revoke the departure permit for any later departure if the agency deems that such later departure may impede the collection of income tax.

If you need to obtain permission to leave and you are not eligible to file Form 2063, you must file Form 1040-C. Generally, all income received or reasonably expected during the tax year prior to the departure date inclusive must be stated on Form 1040-C, and tax on it must be paid. When you pay any tax listed as payable on Form 1040-C, and you file all returns and pay all taxes due for previous years, you receive permission to leave.

If you provide the IRS with information that satisfies the IRS that you intend to return to the United States and that your departure will not jeopardize the collection of income tax, you may be granted permission to leave by completing Form 1040-C without having to pay the tax specified therein. However, you must file all tax returns that have not yet been properly filed and pay all income tax due on those returns. Your Form 1040-C must include all income received and reasonably expected during the entire year of departure.

You must pay all taxes listed as payable on Form 1040-C at the time of filing, unless a lien is granted or the IRS is satisfied that your departure does not prevent the collection of income tax. You must also pay any tax liabilities for past years. If the tax calculation on Form 1040-C results in an overpayment, the tax will not be charged when you file the return. However, the IRS cannot give a refund at the time of departure. If you are entitled to a refund, you must file Form 1040-NR at the end of the tax year.

If you are paying all of your tax liabilities for previous years, you may be able to provide a security deposit to guarantee payment instead of paying the income tax liability shown on your Form 1040-C or on your tax return for the previous year if the filing period for that tax return has not expired.
If you are required by law to file an income tax return, you must file it even if you have already filed a Form 1040-C. Chapters 5 and 7 discuss the procedure for filing an annual income tax return.

Go to IRS.gov/Account to securely access information about your federal tax account. Review the amounts due and the breakdown by tax year. Check the details of the payment agreement or apply for a new payment plan. Make a payment, review the 5-year payment history and any upcoming or scheduled payments. Get online access to tax documents, including key data from your most recent tax return and statements. View electronic copies of some IRS notifications. Approve or reject a request for authorization from a tax professional. Verify your address or select a method for receiving notifications.

With an online account, you can access a variety of information that will help you during the filing process. You can get a tax return, view your most recent tax return, and review your adjusted gross income. Create an online account or access your existing account at IRS.gov/Account.

The safest and easiest way to get a tax refund is to file electronically and opt for Direct Deposit, which ensures that your refund is securely electronically transferred directly to your financial account. Direct Deposit also eliminates the possibility that your check may be lost, stolen, destroyed, or returned to the IRS. Direct Deposit is used by eight out of ten taxpayers to get a refund. If you don't have a bank account, go to IRS.gov/DirectDeposit for more information about where to find a bank or credit union that can open an account online.
For returns that claim an earned income tax credit (EIC) or an additional child tax credit (ACTC), the IRS may not issue a refund until mid-February, which is the earliest the IRS can issue a refund.

Payments for federal tax liabilities must be made to the IRS in U.S. dollars. Digital assets are not accepted. Go to IRS.gov/Payments for more information on how to make a payment using one of the following options. IRS Direct Payment Tool: Pay an individual tax bill or quarterly settlement tax without additional fees directly to your checking or savings account. Debit card, credit card or e-wallet: Choose an approved payment system to pay online or by phone. Electronic withdrawal is offered only when filing federal taxes using the tax preparation software available through your tax preparer or tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax System: Optional for businesses. Payment by mail: You can make a cash transfer from your financial institution on the same day of receipt of your payment, or by sending a money order to the address specified on the invoice, invoice or payment instruction box in the financial institution's mailbox, to see if you have received a receipt or payment within the same day of receipt.

For more information about payment options, visit IRS.gov/Payments. Apply for an online payment agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to pay your taxes in monthly installments if you cannot pay your taxes in full today. Once you complete the online process, you will receive a notification that your agreement has been approved. Use the IRS's Advance Settlement Offer (APO) to see if you can settle your tax debt for less than the full amount of your debt.

Remember that many questions can be answered on IRS.gov without visiting the Taxpayer Assistance Center (TAC). Go to IRS.gov/LetUsHelp for answers to frequently asked questions. If you still need help, TAC provides tax assistance when a tax issue cannot be resolved online or by phone. All TACs currently provide advance registration services, so you'll know in advance that you can get the service you need without waiting too long. Before you visit, go to IRS.gov/TACLocator (English) to find the nearest TAC and find out its hours, available services and appointment options.

The Taxpayer Advisory Service (TAS)  is an independent organization within the IRS that helps taxpayers resolve difficulties arising from their appeal to the IRS, offers administrative and legislative advice to prevent or remedy problems, and protects the rights of taxpayers. We strive to ensure that every taxpayer is treated fairly and that you know and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights. We represent your interests before the IRS.

If you are a sole proprietor or your company is registered as a partnership or an S corporation, you can view your tax information not only by opening a company tax account, but also by opening a business account.

I am a resident of [insert name of country]. I am not a U.S. citizen. 2. I have received an invitation from a U.S. government agency or institution, an educational or scientific research institution in the U.S. to come to the U.S. for the purpose of teaching, conducting research, or participating in scientific, technical, or professional conferences at [insert name of government agency or institution, educational or scientific institution, or organization sponsoring a professional conference], which is a government agency or institution, educational or scientific institution, or organization sponsoring a professional conference. I will receive compensation for my teaching, research, or teaching activities in accordance with the U.S. government's research activities, or for my participation in a research conference, or for the participation in a research conference, or for the participation in a research conference, which is not conducted on the basis of a tax-exemptation agreement with a U.S. governmental organization, or a research contract with a U.S. governmental organization, or a research study conducted by a U.S. governmental organization, or a research organization sponsored by a U. governmental agency or institution, or an educational or scientific institution, or scientific organization, or professional conference sponsoring a professional conference], which is not conducted in the U.S. government's interest.

I am a resident of Germany. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not been granted the privilege of lawful permanent residence in the United States as an immigrant. I am a professor or faculty member in the United States for the purpose of advanced training, teaching or research at [insert name of accredited university, college, school or other educational institution, or public research institution or other institution engaged in research for the benefit of society]. I will receive compensation for my teaching, research or teaching activities. 3. The compensation received during the entire tax year (or period with interest) for this activity meets the criteria for exemption from federal withholding tax under the tax treaty between the United States and Germany. I have not previously claimed exemption from income tax under this particular treaty for the purpose of teaching, teaching or research at [insert name of accredited university, college, school or other educational institution, or public research institution or other institution engaged in research for the benefit of society]. I will receive compensation for my teaching, research or teaching activities. 3. Any benefits accrued during the tax year (or period with interest) for this activity meets the criteria for exemption from federal withholding tax under the treaty between the United States and Germany. I have not previously claimed exemption from paying income tax under this treaty for the purpose of teaching, teaching, teaching or research at [insert name of teaching or research] I have previously applied for this particular university, teaching, taught, taught, taught or taught, taught, taught or taught, taught, taught, taught, or conducted, taught, or received, or received, or received, or received, or received, received, or received, received, or received, or received, or was a scholarship or received, or was a student in the services as a student, or a scholarship, or a, or a, or a, received, received, or a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, an, a, a, a, a, an, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, an, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, a, an, a, a, a, a, a, a, a

You are a resident for tax purposes if you are a lawful permanent resident of the United States at any time during the 2024 calendar year (however, see the "Dual Status Aliens" section below). This is also called the "green card" test. You are a lawful permanent resident of the United States at any time if you have been granted privilege under U.S. immigration law to reside permanently in the United States as an immigrant. You generally have this status if the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) (or its predecessor organization) has issued you a Form I-551 Permanent Resident Card, also known as the green card, which you will continue to have regardless of the type of residence you have chosen, or if you are denied that status by any court or administrative action, regardless of the type of residence you have chosen.

If you file by mail, you must mail the requested income statement (or its foreign equivalent) and keep a copy and proof that it was sent and received by mail. Until you have proof that your letter was received, you remain a resident alien for tax purposes, even if USCIS does not recognize the validity of your "green card" because it is more than 10 years old, or because you have been absent from the United States for a certain period of time. If USCIS or a U.S. consular officer initiates this decision, your resident status will be considered revoked when a final administrative order for waiver of status is issued. If your appeal to a federal court with jurisdiction has been denied, the final determination required by the court of last resort will be upheld.

A foreign government associated individual is an individual (or his or her immediate family member) who is temporarily in the United States... as a staff member of an international organization, either because of his or her diplomatic status or on a visa (other than a visa granting lawful permanent residence), which, as determined by the Department of the Treasury, is issued to individuals who have permanent diplomatic or consular status.
If you are eligible to exclude days of presence in the United States as a teacher or trainee, you must file a completed Form 8843 with the IRS. See the sub-section "Form 8843" below.

Even if you meet the long-term residency criteria, you may be considered a nonresident alien if... you are in the United States for less than 183 days during the year, your tax home is in a foreign country during the year, and you have a closer connection during the year with one foreign country in which your tax home is located than with the United States (unless you have a closer connection with two foreign countries, which will be discussed below).

You can prove that you have a closer connection with two foreign countries (but not more than two) if you meet all of the following conditions: you have a tax residence from the first day of the year in one foreign country; you have changed tax residence during the year to the second foreign country; your tax residence has continued to be in the second foreign country through the end of the year; you have had a closer connection with each foreign country than you have had with the United States during the period your tax residence has continued to be in that foreign country; you have been subject to taxation as a resident under the tax laws of one of the foreign countries for the entire year; or you have been subject to taxation as a resident of both foreign countries during the period your tax residence has been in each foreign country.

Your tax residence is the general area of your principal place of business, work or service, regardless of where you live. Your tax residence is the place where you work permanently or indefinitely as an employee or self-employed person. If you do not have a permanent or principal place of work because of the nature of your business, your tax residence is the place where you regularly reside. If you do not fit into any of these categories, you are considered a migrant, and your tax residence is the place where you work.

It does not matter whether your permanent residence is a house, an apartment or a furnished room, or whether you rent or own a house, but it is important that your home is available to you at all times and not just for a short stay.

The rules here for determining whether you are a U.S. resident do not override the definition of residency in tax treaties. If you are a dual resident taxpayer, you may still qualify for the double taxation treaty benefits. A dual resident taxpayer  is a taxpayer who is a resident of the U.S. and another country under the tax laws of each of those countries. A double taxation treaty between two countries must include a provision for resolving conflicting claims of residency (the "breach clause"). If you are considered a resident of a foreign state under the tax treaty, you are considered a resident of a foreign state for tax purposes in the U.S. for tax purposes. For tax purposes, the rules herein are not considered to be applicable to tax purposes other than the "foreign resident" taxation purposes for which you will be treated as a resident in the U.S. for tax purposes.

If you are a dual resident taxpayer and claim benefits under a double taxation agreement, you must file a return using Form 1040-NR with the attached Form 8833 and calculate your tax as a nonresident alien. A dual resident taxpayer may also be eligible for assistance from the competent U.S. taxing authority. See IRS Tax Procedure 2015-40, 2015-35 I.R.B. 236, available at IRS.gov/irb/2015-35_IRB#RP-2015-40 or its updated version. For more information on reporting benefits under an agreement, see the section "How to Report Claimed Benefits Under an Agreement" in Chapter 9.
You can be both a nonresident alien and a resident alien in the same tax year, usually the year you arrive in the United States or leave the United States.

You cannot file Form 1040 or 1040-SR or this application until you meet the 2025 substantial presence test. If you fail the 2025 test as of April 15, 2025, you may request an extension of time to file your Form 1040 or 1040-SR for 2024 for a reasonable period after you become eligible for long-term residence. To request an extension to file by October 15, 2025, use Form 4868. You may file the form in paper form or use one of the electronic filing options described in the instructions for Form 486. With this extension, you must pay the tax liability for the year 2024 calculated as if you were a resident alien for the entire year.

If you choose to file a joint return, you and your spouse must also change any tax returns you may have filed after the year you chose. Generally, you must file a joint return within 3 years of the original filing date of the U.S. tax return, or within 2 years of the date you paid income tax for that year, whichever is later.
You can only use this date if your tax address was in another country before the end of 2024 or if you had a closer connection with that foreign country.

If you are married at the end of the tax year and one spouse is a U.S. citizen or resident alien and the other spouse is a nonresident alien, you have the option of listing the nonresident spouse as a resident. This also applies to situations where one spouse is a nonresident alien at the beginning of the tax year but a resident alien at the end of the year and the other spouse is a nonresident alien at the end of the year. If you make this choice, you and your spouse will be treated as U.S. residents for income tax purposes for the entire tax year. Neither you nor your spouse can claim under any tax treaty to renounce U.S. residency.

The determination of whether you are a resident alien is suspended for any tax year (after the tax year you have chosen) if neither spouse is a U.S. citizen or resident alien, at any time during the tax year. This means that each spouse must file a separate tax return as a nonresident alien for that year if either of them meets the filing requirements for nonresident aliens described in Chapter 7.

Once you have chosen resident status, it applies to all subsequent years, except for temporary revocation (as explained in the section "Temporary revocation of status") or termination by one of the following means. If the choice has been terminated by one of the following means, neither spouse may make this choice in any subsequent tax year. 1. Cancellation. Any spouse may cancel the choice for any tax year provided that he or she completes the cancellation by the due date for filing the tax return for that tax year. The spouse who cancels the choice must attach a signed statement that the choice is being canceled. The statement must state the name, address and identification number (TIN) of each spouse. (If the choice has been terminated by one of the spouses, the deceased spouse may not make this choice in any subsequent tax year, provided that he or she fulfills the cancellation by the due date for filing the tax return for that tax year. However, if the spouse has the same name and address as the spouse, the spouse must file a joint return for the tax return, even if the spouse is not a U.S. citizen, and the spouse has the same last name and address for filing the tax return, and must file the cancellation application for the next year, even if the spouse is not a U.S.

The income of a resident alien is generally taxed in the same way as the income of a U.S. citizen. If you are a resident alien, you must report all interest, dividends, wages or other service payments, income from renting property or royalties, and other income on your U.S. tax return. You must report these amounts from sources in the United States and abroad.

Nonresident aliens are taxed only on their income from sources in the United States and on certain income associated with the conduct of a professional or commercial activity in the United States (see Chapter 4). The general rules for determining income from sources in the United States applicable to most nonresident aliens are shown in Table 2-1. The following discussions cover the general rules as well as exceptions to these rules. Not all items of income from sources in the United States are taxable.
