Real estate is land and buildings, and in general everything that is built on, grows on, or attached to land. Property gross income from sources in the United States includes the increase, profit, and income from the sale or other disposition of real property located in the United States.

Income from the sale of any farm, mine, oil or gas well, other natural deposit or timber located in the United States and sold in a foreign state, or located in a foreign state and sold in the United States, is partly income from sources in the United States.

Personal property  is property such as machinery, equipment, or furniture that is not real property. Gains or losses from the sale or exchange of personal property are generally sourced in the United States if your tax home is in the United States. If your tax home is not in the United States, the gains or losses are generally considered to have been derived from sources outside the United States.

If you do not have a permanent or fixed place of work because of the nature of your business, your tax residence is the place where you regularly reside. If you do not fall into any of these categories, you are considered to be a person moving from one place to another, and your tax residence is the place where you work.

Inventory  is personal property used in trade, or primarily intended for sale to buyers in the course of ordinary professional or commercial activity. The income from the sale of inventory you purchase is considered to be received at the place of sale of that property. Generally, this is the place where ownership of the property passes to the buyer. For example, income from the sale of inventory in the U.S. is income from a source in the U.S., regardless of whether you purchased it in the U.S. or in another country. The income from the sale of inventory that you produced in the U.S. and sold outside the U.S. (or vice versa) is the income from the place where that property was produced. These rules apply even if your tax residence is not in the U.S.

To determine the source of income from the sale of depreciable personal property, you must first calculate the portion of the income that does not exceed the total amount of depreciation adjustments on the property. You distribute this portion of the income among sources in the U.S. based on the ratio of depreciation adjustments in the U.S. to the total amount of depreciation adjustments. The remaining portion of the income is considered to be derived from sources outside the U.S. In this case, the "depreciation adjustments in the U.S". are depreciation adjustments to the property base that are allowed when calculating taxable income from sources in the U.S. However, if the property is predominantly used in the U.S. during the tax year, all depreciation adjustments are allocated to sources in the U.S. based on the ratio of depreciation adjustments in the U.S. to the total amount of depreciation adjustments on the property. If the property is used for commercial purposes, it is considered to be depreciation adjusted for the cost of the property, and if the depreciation adjustment is less than the amount of the cost of the property used in the U.S.

Intangible property includes patents, copyrights, secret processes or formulas, goodwill, trademarks, trade names, and other similar property. Profit from the sale of depreciable or depreciable intangible property within the limits of previously authorized depreciation or depreciation deductions is accounted for in the same way as the original deductions. This rule is similar to the source rule for profit from the sale of depreciable property. See the "Depreciable property" subsection above for details on how to apply this rule. Profit exceeding depreciation deductions is considered to be a source in the country where the property is used if the income from the sale was dependent on the production or use of the goodwill, or if the income is not dependent on the country where the goodwill was produced, or if the income is not dependent on the source of the goodwill, or if the income is not determined by the country where the goodwill was created, or if the income is not dependent on the source of the goodwill, or if the income is not determined by the country where the goodwill was created.

Notwithstanding any of the preceding rules, if your tax home is not in the United States but you have an office or other permanent place of business in the United States, income from any sale of personal property (including inventory) related to that office or place of business is considered income from a source in the United States. However, this rule does not apply to the sale of inventory property for use, disposal, or consumption outside the United States if your office or other permanent place of business outside the United States took a substantial part in the sale. If you have a taxable home in the United States but you have an office or other permanent place of business outside the United States, income from the sale of personal property (including inventory) related to that office or place of business is considered income from a source in the United States, unless less than 10% of the income from the sale of immovable property or inventory from a foreign source is taxable as income from the sale of immovable property, or if less than 10% of the income from the sale of immovable property is taxable as income from a foreign source, which would be taxable in the United States if the income from the sale of immovable property or inventory from a foreign source was taxable in the United States.

Interest income from sources in the United States does not include the following items: 1. Interest paid by a resident alien or a national corporation on liabilities issued prior to August 10, 2010, if, in the three-year period ending with the end of the taxpayer's tax year preceding the payment of interest, not less than 80% (0.80) of the total gross income... 1. derived from sources outside the United States, and 2. related to the active pursuit of a professional or commercial activity by a natural or legal person in another country or in a territory administered by the United States. However, interest will be considered to be interest income from sources in the United States if one of the following conditions applies: 1. The recipient of interest is connected with a resident alien or a local corporation.

In most cases, dividend income received from domestic corporations is income from sources in the U.S. Dividend income from foreign corporations is usually income from a foreign source. The exception to the second rule is discussed later. The replacement dividend payment to the person transferring the securities in a securities lending or reverse repurchase transaction is accounted for in the same manner as the distribution on the transferred securities.

As a result, a taxpayer may be considered to have received a payment equivalent to dividends even if the taxpayer makes a net payment or pays no amount because the net amount is zero. In 2024, the NPC or ELI will typically be the specified NPC or ELI, respectively, if the contract relates to derivative financial instrument transactions of the same type as the delta. Typically, this is the ratio of the fair market value of the delta to the fair market value of the NPC or ELI after the change in the fair market value of the NPC or ELI has been accounted for in the contract (see the following table in the section on fair market value of the NPC or ELI after the change in the fair market value of the NPC or ELI). For the purpose of the 2024 smart contract, the NPC-4 is a small amount of additional information that is required to be included in the accounting rules for the accounting of the fair market value of the NPC or ELI after the change in the fair market value of the NPC-471 or ELI-1571 is included in the accounting rules for the smart contract (see the following table in the section on fair market value of the NPC-471 or ELI-154).

All wages and any other remuneration for services performed in the United States are considered to have been received from sources in the United States. The only exceptions to this rule are discussed in the subsection "Employees of foreign persons, organizations or offices" below, and in the subsection "Crew members" above. If you are an employee and receive remuneration for labor or personal services performed both in the United States and abroad, special rules apply when determining the source of the remuneration. The remuneration (except for certain additional benefits) is determined on a time basis. Certain additional benefits (such as housing and education) are determined on a geographical basis. Or you may be allowed to use an alternative basis for determining the source of the remuneration. See the section "Alternative basis" below for a more detailed explanation.

Some companies sell products under a multi-level marketing scheme, whereby a top-level distributor who sponsored a lower-level distributor is entitled to payments from the company based on certain actions of that lower-level distributor. Typically, depending on the facts, payments from such multi-level marketing companies to independent (non-employee) distributors (upper-level distributors) based on sales or purchases by the persons they sponsored (lower-level distributors) constitute income for performing personal services to attract, train and support lower-level distributors. The source of such income is usually dependent on the location of the services provided by the top-level distributor and may, depending on the facts, be considered a multi-year remuneration, with the source of income being determined by the amount of income earned by the company during the same period.

The source of the multi-year benefit is usually determined on a time basis over the period to which the benefit relates. A multi-year benefit  is a benefit that is included in your income in one tax year but relates to a period that includes 2 or more tax years. You determine the period to which the benefit relates based on the facts and circumstances of your case. For example, a benefit amount that relates to a time period that includes several calendar years relates to the entire multi-year period. The benefit amount considered to be received from sources in the U.S. is determined by multiplying the total benefit amount over the multi-year period by the fractional. The numerator  is the number of days (or less than a day's time unit if applicable) during which you performed labor or personal services in connection with a U.S. project, or the denominator  is used if the total number of days in which you performed labor or personal services in connection with a U.S. project is less than one day (or the denominator  is used if the total number of days in which you performed labor or personal services in connection with a U.S.S. project is used).

The above additional benefits, except for the reimbursement of taxes paid and payments for work in hazardous or difficult conditions, are calculated by the main place of work. The main place of work is usually the place where you spend most of your working time. This can be your office, factory, shop, store or other place. If there is no such place where you spend most of your working time, then your main place of work  is the place where your work is concentrated, such as where you come to work or are required to  carry out your work. If you have several jobs at the same time, the location of your main job depends on the facts in each specific case. The most important factors to consider are how much time you spend in each place, the amount of work you do in each place, and how much money you earn in each place.

The source of education allowance to cover the education expenses of your dependants is determined by the location of your main place of work.The education allowance includes payment of only the following expenses for primary or secondary school education.Tuition fees, fees, academic tutoring, services for pupils with special needs, books, supplies and other equipment.Room and board and uniforms that are required or provided by the school in connection with enrolment or attendance.
The source of the refund of taxes paid is the jurisdiction which has imposed the tax for which you are receiving the refund.

The source of reimbursement of the costs of moving is usually determined by the place of your new main place of work. However, the source is determined by the place of your previous main place of work if you provide sufficient evidence that such a source is more correct in accordance with the facts and circumstances of your case. Sufficient evidence usually requires an agreement between you and your employer or a written statement of the company's policy that was drawn up before the move and concluded or established with the aim of encouraging you or other employees to move to another country. The written statement or agreement must state that your employer will reimburse you for the costs of moving that you have incurred to return to your previous main place of work, regardless of whether you continue to work for your employer after returning to that place of work. It may contain certain conditions, depending on the right of residence, which can only be determined if you have met the standards or conditions set out in the regulations governing the right of residence of your employer, or if you have been disqualified from the workplace for a period of time.

If you are an employee, you may determine the source of your compensation on an alternative basis if you prove to the IRS that, according to the facts and circumstances of your case, the alternative basis more correctly determines the source of your compensation than the temporary or geographic basis. If you use an alternative basis, you must keep documentation (including verification) proving why the alternative basis more correctly determines the source of your compensation. Also, if the total amount of compensation from all sources is $250,000 or more, answer Yes to both questions on line K of the OI Appendix (Form 1040-NR), and attach to your tax return a written statement that states the following: 1. Your name and Social Security Number (SSN) (as listed at the top of the statement). 2. The manner in which you have used the alternative basis to calculate the amount of compensation, and (2) the manner in which you have used the alternative basis to calculate the amount of compensation, and (3) the manner in which you have used the alternative basis.

The term "ship" includes any container used in connection with a ship. All revenue from shipments that begin and end in the United States is treated as derived from sources in the United States. If the shipment begins or ends in the United States, 50% of the revenue from the shipment is treated as derived from sources in the United States. Revenue from the shipment, which is part of a personal service, is treated as income from sources in the United States if the shipment is from a single source and the principal source is from a U.S. territory, or income from a foreign-born resident of the United States, as if the shipment were derived from a single source.

If you receive a pension from a national fund for services rendered both in the United States and abroad, a portion of the pension payments comes from sources in the United States. This portion is the amount related to pension plan income and employer contributions made for services rendered in the United States. This rule applies regardless of whether the payments are made under a qualified or non-qualified stock-based compensation plan, pension plan, profit-sharing plan, or annuity (whether it is cumulative or not). If you worked as a U.S. employee, you may receive a distribution from the U.S. government under a plan such as the U.S. Government Employees' Retirement System, which is considered to be qualified pension plan income. Your income from outside the United States is the amount of taxable income that is excluded from your basic payroll tax credit, which is exempt from the U.S. Government's basic payroll tax credit, and is not covered by the U.S. Taxpayer Insurance Corporation's basic payroll tax credit.

Your US source income includes income from real estate and royalties received during the tax year from property located in the US, or from any interest in that property. US source income also includes income from real estate or royalties for the use or privilege of using intangible property in the US, such as patents, copyrights, secret processes and formulae, goodwill, trademarks, franchises and similar property.
In these cases, you and your spouse must declare your joint income as described below.

The spouse's earned income, except for income from professional or commercial activities and the spouse's share in the partnership's income, is treated as the income of the spouse whose services have brought the income.

The income from a professional or commercial activity other than the distribution of the partner's share of the partnership's income is treated as the income of the spouse of the deceased who is engaged in a professional or commercial activity.
The partner's share of the partnership's income (or loss) is treated as the partner's income (or loss).

If you are married, income from a separate property of one of the spouses (and which is not earned income, income from a professional or commercial activity, or income from a partnership's distributive share) is treated as the income of that spouse.

The gross income exclusion is generally income that you earn but that is not included in your U.S. income and is not taxed in the U.S. This chapter discusses some of the most common exclusions allowed to resident aliens and nonresident aliens.

Interest income not related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States is excluded from income if it relates to... Deposits (including certificates of deposit) in financial institutions; Deposits or withdrawal accounts in mutual savings banks, cooperative banks, credit unions, local building and credit associations, and other savings institutions registered and controlled as savings and credit or similar associations under federal or state law (if the interest paid or credited may be deducted by the association); and Amounts withheld by an insurance company under an agreement to pay interest thereon.

Interest on liabilities of a state or political subdivision, the District of Columbia, or a U.S. territory is not generally included in income, but interest on certain private-equity bonds, arbitrage bonds, and certain unregistered bonds is.

Interest not taxable does not include contingent interest. Conditional interest is any of the following: 1. Interest that is determined by reference to... any receipts, sales, or other cash flows of the debtor or a related person; the income or profit of the debtor or a related person; any change in value of any property of the debtor or a related person; or any dividends, partnership payments, or similar payments made by the debtor or a related person. For exceptions, see section 871 (h) (iv) (iv) (C). 2. Any other type of contingent interest that is determined by the Minister of Finance in the regulations.
The next dividend income is exempt from tax at 30%.

The 30% tax on dividends with US sources that you receive from a foreign corporation is excluded. See the "Exclusion" sub-section in the "Dividends" section of Chapter 2 for details on how to determine the amount of dividends with US sources. This exemption does not apply to payments equivalent to dividends.
The dividend yield on interest-bearing dividends from sources in the United States that you receive from a mutual fund or other managed investment company (RIC) is exempt from the income tax.

The tax of 30% on certain short-term capital gains dividends from sources in the United States that you receive from a mutual fund or other managed investment company (RIC) may not be levied. The mutual fund will determine in writing which dividends are short-term capital gains dividends. This tax deduction will not apply to you if you are in the United States for 183 days or more during your tax year.
If you were paid by a foreign employer, your income from sources in the United States may be tax-exempt in the United States, but only if you fall into one of the categories discussed below.

If you do not meet all three conditions, your income from household services rendered in the United States is income with a source in the United States and is taxable under the rules of Chapter 4. If your fee for these services exceeds $3,000, the entire amount is income from professional or commercial activities in the United States. To find out if your salary exceeds $3,000, do not include the amount you receive from your employer as an advance or reimbursement of travel expenses if you were required to report to your employer for these expenses. If the advances or compensation exceed your expenses, include the amount in your fee for these services.
The term "foreign employer" does not include a foreign government. Payments made by a foreign government exempt from U.S. income tax are discussed in Chapter 10.

Income of any kind that is exempt from taxation in the United States under a treaty to which the United States is a party is excluded from your gross income. However, income that is taxed only by the treaty is included in your gross income. See Chapter 9.

If you sold your main home, you can deduct up to $250,000 in gains from the sale of your home. If you are married and filing a joint return, you can deduct up to $500,000. For information on the requirements for this deduction, see Publication No. 523 (English). This deduction does not apply if you are covered by the expatriation tax rules described in Chapter 4 of the Income Tax Act of the United States of America.

If you are a candidate for a degree, you may exclude from your income some or all of the amounts you receive as qualifying scholarship. The rules discussed here apply to both resident and nonresident aliens. If a nonresident alien receives a grant from non-U.S. sources, he or she is not subject to U.S. taxation. Please see the section "Scholarships, Grants, Awards, and Prizes" in Chapter 2 to determine whether your grant is from U.S. sources. The scholarship or scholarship grant is excluded from your income only if... 1. you are a candidate for a degree at the relevant institution, and 2. you use the scholarship or scholarship grant to pay for qualifying education expenses.

Resident aliens and nonresident aliens are taxed differently. Resident aliens are generally taxed in the same way as U.S. citizens. Nonresident aliens are taxed based on the source of their income and whether their income is actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States. The following information will help you determine whether income you received during the tax year is actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States and how it is taxed.

Foreign residents are generally taxed in the same way as U.S. citizens. This means that their worldwide income is taxed in the U.S. and must be reported on their U.S. tax return. Foreign resident income is taxed at the differentiated tax rates that apply to U.S. citizens. Foreign resident individuals use the Taxation Schedule or Taxation Schedule, which is placed in the instructions for Form 1040, which applies to U.S. citizens.

The difference between the two categories is that the actual related income after allowable deductions is taxed at differentiated rates. These are the same rates that apply to U.S. citizens and residents. Income that is not directly related is taxed at a flat rate of 30% (or lower than the contractual rate). If you were previously a U.S. citizen or resident alien, these rules may not apply.

In general, you must be engaged in a business during the tax year in order to be able to consider the income earned in that year as actually related to that business or professional activity. e.g. whether you are engaged in a business or professional activity in the United States depends on the nature of your business. e.g. the following discussion will help you determine whether you are engaged in a business or professional activity in the United States. e.g. whether you are a resident of the United States or a resident of Canada. e.g. whether you are a resident of the United States or a resident of Canada. e.g. whether you are a resident of the United States or a resident of Canada. e.g. whether you are a resident of Canada or a resident of Canada. e.g. whether you are a resident of Canada or a resident of Canada. e.g. if you are a resident of Canada, you must be a resident of Canada.

If you provide household services in the United States at any time during the tax year, it is generally considered that you are engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States. Certain remuneration paid to a nonresident alien by a foreign employer is not included in gross income. For more information, see the section "Work performed for a foreign employer" in Chapter 3.

If you are temporarily in the United States as a nonimmigrant on an F, J, M, or Q visa and are not engaged in a business activity, you are considered to be engaged in a business activity in the United States if you have taxable income from receiving a scholarship or a grant described in section 1441 (b) (i).The taxable portion of any scholarship or grant that is income from a source in the United States is treated as being actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States.

If your sole activity in the United States is trading in stocks, securities, or commodities (including hedging transactions) through a U.S. resident broker or other agent, you are not engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States. For transactions in stocks or securities, this applies to any non-resident alien, including a stock and securities dealer or broker. For transactions in commodities, this applies to commodities that are normally sold and purchased on an organized commodity exchange and to transactions that are normally conducted on such an exchange. This exception does not apply if you have a U.S. office or other permanent place of business at any time during the tax year through which or at the direction of which you transact in stocks, securities, or commodities.

You are not engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States if trading in stocks, securities, or commodities for your own account is your only activity in the United States. This rule applies even if the trading is conducted while you are in the United States or is conducted by your employee, your broker, or other agent. This does not apply to trading for your own account if you are a stock, securities, or commodities dealer. However, this does not necessarily mean that you are engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States as a dealer. You must determine this on the basis of the facts and circumstances of each individual case or in accordance with the rules set forth above in the section entitled "Trading in Stocks, Securities, and Commodities".

If you are engaged in a professional or business activity in the United States, then all income, profit or loss for the tax year that you received from sources in the United States (except certain investment income) is considered as income actually related to the business activity in the United States. This rule applies regardless of whether there is any connection between the income and the professional or business activity carried out in the United States during the tax year. The two tests described in the Investment Income section determine whether certain items of investment income, such as interest, dividends and royalties, are considered to be actually related to the business. In rare cases, some types of income from foreign sources may be considered to be actually related to the professional or business activity in the United States. See the explanation of these rules in the Foreign Income section below.

Use the two tests described below to determine whether income from a U.S. source that falls into one of the three categories and was received during the tax year is actually related to your professional or commercial activities in the U.S. If the tests show that the income is actually related, you must include it as part of other actually related income. If the income is not actually related, include it along with all other income discussed in the "Taxation at 30%" section below this chapter.
According to this test, if the professional or commercial activity in the United States was a significant factor in the earning of income, then the income is considered to be effectively connected.

If you provide personal services in the United States, you are considered to be engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States. Income from personal services you received during the tax year in which you engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States is actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States. Income received in a year other than the year of the service is also actually related if it was actually related, you will receive that income in the year of the service. Personal service income includes wages, salaries, commissions, fees, per diem, and bonuses and allowances to employees. Income may be paid to you in cash or in the form of property. If you engage in a professional or commercial activity in the United States only because during the tax year you are engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States, and the income from personal services is actually related to a professional or commercial activity, then there is no connection between the income from the ownership of assets and the income from the sale of those assets, or the income from the exchange of profits or losses, or the income from the sale of capital, as a rule, or the transfer of assets, or receipt of income from a business activity, or the provision of services.

Permanent place of business generally means a place, facility, building or other similar structure through which you engage in professional or commercial activities. Regular transportation means that a sea or air vessel follows a published schedule with repeating flights or flights through regular intervals between the same points for flights or flights that begin or end in the U.S. This definition applies to both regular and charter air transportation. If you do not meet the two conditions above, the income is not actually tied and is taxed at the 4% rate. See the "Transportation Tax" subsection below in this chapter.

For example, a profit from the sale in the United States of inventory of goods and services acquired either in this country or in another country is not actually related to income from a professional or commercial activity.

This is any interest in real property located in the United States or the U.S. Virgin Islands, or any interest (other than as a creditor) in a national corporation that is a corporation that owns real property in the United States. Real property includes the following: 1. Land and unused natural products of the land, such as growing crops and timber, as well as mines, wells, and other natural deposits. 2. Improvements to the land, including buildings, other permanent structures, and their structural components. 3. Personal property associated with the use of real property, such as equipment used in agriculture, mining, forestry, or construction, or property used in hotels or offices, except when the property is sold or used for personal use for more than 1 year after the property is purchased, or 2. Real property associated with a person's property, property, or personal property, excluding real estate, which is sold or used for more than 1 year after the property is purchased.
If you sell a share in a US property, the buyer may have to withhold the tax. See the explanation under "Tax withheld on the sale of real estate" in Chapter 8.

The shares of any national corporation are not considered shares of any U.S. corporation that owns real estate unless you can prove that the corporation is not a U.S. corporation that owns real estate.

A U.S. real estate investment trust does not include a class of corporate stock that is regularly bought and sold on an organized securities market, unless you own more than 5% of the fair market value of that class of stock (or more than 10% of the stock in the case of a real estate investment trust (REIT)).A foreign corporation holding U.S. real estate is not normally a U.S. real estate investment trust unless the corporation decides that it should be treated as a domestic corporation.

Special rules apply to qualifying investment companies (QIE). A QIE  is any real estate investment trust (REIT) or any regulated investment company (RIC) that is treated as a U.S. corporation owning real estate (after applying certain rules in section 897 (h) (4) (A) (ii)). See the section Real Property Interest (A Share in Real Property in the U.S.) in Publication No. 515 (English).

In most cases, any payment by a QIE to a non-resident alien, foreign corporation, or other QIE that relates to QIE income from the sale or exchange of a share in U.S. real estate during the 1 year period of the exchange is treated as income recognized by the non-resident alien, foreign corporation, or other QIE from the sale or exchange of a share in U.S. real estate. Certain exceptions apply to the squeeze test for payments from a QIE. A QIE payment in respect of shares regularly traded on a regulated securities market in the U.S. is not treated as income from the sale or exchange of a share in U.S. real estate if the shareholder owns 5% or less of those shares (or less of those shares in a REIT in any case) during the 1 year period of the exchange, and is treated as income recognized by the non-resident alien, foreign corporation, or other QIE from the sale or exchange of a share in U.S. real estate. A QIE payment in respect of shares regularly traded on an organized securities market in the U.S. is not treated as income from the sale or exchange of 5% or less of those shares (or 10% or less of those shares in a REIT in any case) during the 1 year period of the exchange, unless the payment is included in the dividend income from the payment of income from the payment of the dividends, or the U.S. REIT, or the date of the sale, which is not included in the ordinary income, is not included in the ordinary income taxable income taxable income taxable income tax, or share, as described in the REIT, or the ordinary income taxable income taxable income taxable income of the sale (as) is not included in the REIT (as) (assuitable Income, or unincome taxable property property property (as) (assuited to be classified as of the date of the sale (assuitable share, not included in the REIT, not included in the ordinary share, unlisted property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property property (as) (assuitable to be classified as of the exchange)

For the purposes of determining whether a QIE is domestically controlled, the following rules apply: 1. A person owning less than 5% of the shares of any class of QIE that are regularly traded and purchased on a regulated securities market in the United States during the entire period of the review will be treated as a U.S. person unless QIE has factual information that such person is not a U.S. person. 2. Any shares of a QIE that are owned by another QIE will be treated as being owned by a foreign person if... 1. any class of shares of such other QIE is regularly traded and purchased on a regulated securities market, or 2. such other QIE is an RIC that issues certain of the securities being purchased. Notwithstanding the foregoing, any shares of a QIE that are owned by such other class of QIE that are regularly traded and purchased on a regulated securities market in the United States during the entire period of the review will be treated as being owned by such other class of QIE unless QIE has actual knowledge that such other QIE is owned by a foreign person. 3. any class of shares of such other QIE that are owned by such other QIE that are not listed in the United States will be treated as being owned by any other class of QIE.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner in a U.S. or foreign partnership that engages (or is deemed to engage) in a professional or commercial activity in the U.S. and you directly or indirectly sell that interest, the gain or loss on the sale of that interest in the partnership may affect your federal tax liability. Under Section 864 (c) (a), your gain or loss on the sale, exchange, or other alienation of an interest in the partnership is treated as actually related to the conduct of a professional or commercial activity in the U.S. (the "actual connected gain" or "actual connected loss" provisions). However, the amount of actual connected gain or loss is limited to what would have been the portion of your distributable share in the partnership that would have been the actual distribution of the interest in the partnership, or other types of gain or loss that would have been incurred after the date of the sale, or the date of the sale, if the fair market value of the shares or other types of profit transferred by the partnership had not been published on or after the date of the sale, which is the same as the date of the sale, or the sale.

Any income from a foreign source that is equivalent to any of the income items described above is treated as being actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the U.S. For example, interest and dividend equivalents from a foreign source are treated as being actually related to the U.S. if the income is derived by a foreign entity from the active conduct of a banking, financial, or similar business in the U.S.

If you are a resident alien, you are not required to pay income tax on your income tax return, and if you are a resident alien, you are not required to pay income tax on your income tax return. If you are a resident alien, you are not required to pay income tax on your income tax return, and you are not required to pay income tax on your income tax return, you are not required to pay income tax on your income tax return.
You may be able to classify all of your income from real estate as income directly related to your activities in the U.S. See the "Real estate income" sub-section below in this section.
The 30% tax rate (or lower) applies to certain items of income or profit from sources in the US, but only if those items are not related to your professional or commercial activities in the US.

The 30% (or lower by contract) rate applies to the gross amount of fixed, determinable, annual, or periodic (FDAP) profit, revenue, or income from a U.S. source. Income is considered fixed when it is paid in amounts known in advance. Other income is determined whenever there is a basis for determining the amount to be paid. Income may be periodic if it is paid from time to time. It may not be paid annually or at regular intervals. Income may be determinable or periodic even if the length of time over which payments are made increases or decreases. Items specifically included as taxable fixed or determinable income are interest (except for the initial discount on the issuance of an income tax return (IDO)), dividends, capital gains, dividend premiums, or other payments received as part of a defined income tax credit, such as dividends paid on capital gains, dividends paid on dividends, or other payments made on income not subject to U.S. taxation, such as dividends paid on dividends, or other payments made as part of a fixed income tax credit, such as dividends paid on capital gains, or other payments not subject to U.S. taxation, such as the payment of dividends, interest on the purchase of securities, or payment of securities, or other payments of the same value) may be paid in the same amount of the transaction.

Non-resident aliens are generally subject to a 30% tax on gross income from gambling won in the United States, unless that income is directly related to a professional or commercial activity in the U.S. and is exempt from tax under the agreement. However, income from gambling that is not a commercial enterprise is not taxable if the non-resident alien wins in the U.S. in blackjack, baccarat, craps, roulette or a big six wheel. Non-resident aliens are taxed at differentiated rates on net income from gambling received in the United States that is actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the U.S. Under the tax agreements, this income from gambling is exempt from tax.

The nonresident alien must include 85% of any Social Security fund payments (and the equivalent portion of the Social Security Level 1 Railroad Pension Payments) in a source of fixed, defined, annual, or periodic income in the U.S. Social Security fund payments include monthly pension payments, bereavement and disability payments. This income is exempt from taxation under some tax treaties. See the section Table 1 on the Table of Tax Treaties web page available at IRS.gov/TreatyTables (English) for a list of tax treaties exempting U.S. Social Security fund payments from U.S. taxation. For more information, see Publication No. 915 (English)

If you are not engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States and have not established a tax year for the previous period, your tax year will be a calendar year for the 183 day rule.

If you have income from a property located in the United States that you own in whole or in part, and you acquired it for the purpose of earning income, you may treat all income from that property as income actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States. This selection applies to all income from real estate located in the United States and intended to earn income, and to all income from any interest in such property. It includes income from leases, royalties from mines, oil or gas wells, or other natural resources. It also includes income from the sale or exchange of timber, coal, or domestic iron ore with an interest in preserving economic viability. You may make this selection only as income from a professional or commercial activity in the United States, and you may not be eligible for this selection if you are a resident of the United States and do not engage in any business activity in the United States. This selection may be made on the basis of your income from a commercial activity in the United States, or any other manner that is not related to your professional or commercial activity, regardless of your status as a U.S. resident, and will not be taxable in the United States.

This 4% tax applies to your gross transportation income from the United States. This only includes transportation income that is considered to be derived from sources in the United States if the transportation begins or ends in the United States. To receive transportation and household income, the transportation must occur between the United States and a U.S. administered territory. For a non-resident alien's household income, this only applies to income derived from an aircraft or something related to it.

Under this special rule, you are taxed on gross income and profits from your source in the United States on a net basis at the differential rates applicable to individuals (with allowable deductions) for the period during which you were a nonresident alien, unless you would be subject to a higher tax rate under Section 871 (the rules that would normally apply to taxation of nonresident alien income are discussed above) after accounting for any applicable contractual privileges.

If you are taxed for any year during which you were a nonresident alien, you must file Form 1040-NR for that year. The tax return must be filed by the due date (including the extension) for filing your U.S. income tax return for the year you become a U.S. resident again. If you have already filed returns for that period, you must file amended returns. You must attach to your return a statement indicating the source of all your gross income in the U.S. and abroad, and the items of income subject to this special rule.

You must file the original Form 8854 in the year you renounce U.S. citizenship or end your long-term residency, even if you are not required to pay expatriation tax. Additionally, you must file Form 8854 annually after your expatriation if you were required to pay expatriation tax and have 1. deferred tax at current market value (see "Deferred tax at current market value" below), 2. you have a deferred compensation class designation, or 3. you have a right to receive income from trust assets without a fiduciary.

If you emigrated after June 16, 2008, you are considered a protected expatriate and the expatriation rules of Section 877A apply to you if you meet any of the following conditions: (1) your average annual net income tax for the 5 years ending before the date of departure or termination of residence is more than $201,000 if you emigrated or terminated residence in the United States in 2024, (2) your net worth is $2 million or more on the date of your departure or termination of residence, (3) you fail to certify on Form 8854 that you have met all of your U.S. federal tax obligations for the 5 years preceding the date of your departure or termination of residence.

In the year you leave abroad, you are taxed on the net unrealized gain (or loss) on your property as if the property had been sold at fair market value the day before you left abroad (mark-to-market tax). This applies to most types of property interest that you owned on the date of renunciation of citizenship or termination of residency. But see the "Exclusions" subsection below. The gain from the intended sales must be accounted for in the tax year of the intended sale without regard to other tax laws.

Instead, in clauses (1) and (3), the tax may be withheld initially.In the case of clause (2), it is deemed that you receive the current value of the benefits you accrued the day before your date of expatriation.In the case of clause (4), it is deemed that you receive the distribution of your entire share in the account the day before your date of expatriation.For more information, see Notice 2009-85 and the instructions to Form 8854.

Once you have determined your status as a resident alien, the source of your income, and whether that income is taxable in the United States (and if so, what it is), your next step is to calculate your tax. The information in this chapter is not as comprehensive for resident aliens as it is for non-resident aliens. Therefore, resident aliens should use the publications, forms, and instructions for U.S. citizens, because the tax filing information for resident aliens is generally the same as for U.S. citizens. If you are both a resident alien and a non-resident alien in the same tax year, see Chapter 6 for discussion of dual resident aliens.

Nonresident aliens may qualify for the same itemized deductions as resident aliens, but nonresident aliens may only claim itemized deductions if they have income that is actually related to their professional or commercial activities in the U.S. There may be restrictions affecting the amount of itemized deductions you may claim in Appendix A. See the instructions for Appendix A (Form 1040) or the instructions for Appendix A (Form 1040-NR)  Itemized deductions in the instructions for Form 1040-NR (English).
You can claim the same itemized deductions as U.S. citizens by using Appendix A (Form 1040) and the instruction manual for Appendix A (Form 1040) for more information.

You can deduct certain itemized deductions if you receive income that is actually related to your professional or commercial activities in the U.S. Generally, you can only include deductions and losses that are properly allocated and proportionate to income that is actually related to your professional or commercial activities in the U.S. You cannot include deductions and/or losses that relate to deductible income or to income that is not directly related to professional or commercial activities in the U.S. However, you can deduct certain charitable contributions and losses from accidents and theft, even if they are not related to your income that is obviously related to doing business in the taxable territory.
Non-resident foreigners cannot claim the standard deduction, however, for certain Indian foreigners temporarily residing in the United States, there is a special rule, as described below.

Special rules apply to students and business interns who are eligible for benefits under Section 21 (2) of the U.S.-India Double Taxation Avoidance Agreement. You may claim the standard deduction provided you are not eligible for the itemized deductions. Use Worksheet 5-1 to calculate your standard deduction for 2024. If you are married and your spouse files a tax return and specifies the itemized deductions, you cannot use the standard deduction.

If you are a student or business intern eligible for benefits under Section 21 (2) of the U.S.-India Double Taxation Avoidance Agreement who has been affected by certain major federal disasters in 2024 (see IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief and FEMA.gov/Disasters), you may elect to increase the standard deduction by any qualified personal disaster loss on your 2024 tax return. Use Worksheet 5-1 to calculate your 2024 standard deduction.

You can deduct state and local income tax that you paid on income actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States. Your deduction is limited to $10,000 (US$5,000 for married individuals filing separately). If you received a refund or refund from an overpaid amount of taxes paid in the previous year in 2024, do not deduct the deduction by this amount. Instead, you should include the refund or refund from an overpaid amount in income if you deducted taxes in the previous year and the deduction reduced your tax.

You may, with some restrictions, deduct charitable donations or gifts to eligible organizations. Qualified organizations include religious, charitable, educational, scientific, or literary organizations, and organizations that work to prevent cruelty to children or animals. Certain organizations that develop national or international amateur sports competitions also meet the criteria. For more information about charitable deductions, see the section Gifts to U.S. charities in the instructions for Appendix A (Form 1040-NR) Postal deductions and instructions for Form 1040-NR (English)  in the section Gifts to U.S. charities in the section Gifts to U.S. charities in the section Gifts to U.S. charities in the section Gifts to U.S. charities in the section Gifts to U.S. charities in the section Gifts to U.S. charities in the section Gifts to U.S. charities in the section

You can deduct accidental damage and theft on your tax return. You can deduct non-commercial accidental damage or theft damage only if it is caused by a federally significant natural disaster. If the accident or theft happened to you as a result of a federally significant natural disaster, you can deduct the loss even if your property is not related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States. The property may be property for personal use or bring income not related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States.

For more information, see the instructions to line 7 in the instructions for Appendix A (Form 1040-NR) Statutory deductions in the instructions for Form 1040-NR (English). See also Publication No. 529 (English).

You may claim a credit, subject to certain limitations, for income tax paid or credited to you in a foreign country on income from a foreign source. You may not claim a credit for taxes paid or credited on excluded foreign income.

If a person does not have an SNN (or ITIN) issued on or before the filing date of the 2024 return (including the extension), such person cannot claim a child tax credit and an additional child tax credit on the original 2024 return or on the amended return. If your child did not have an SSN valid for employment issued before the 2024 return (including the extension), you may designate this child for the tax credit claim for the extension and other dependents, but not for the tax claim for the child. Use the following account, "Tax Credit, Payable Debt and Other Dependents" (F12), to provide the amount of your child's tax credit (F12), if you have used the 8840 Uses.U.S. Appendix 10 (F12).

The other dependent credit is for people who have dependents who cannot qualify for a child tax credit. The eligible dependent must be a U.S. citizen, a non-incorporated territory resident, or a resident alien, and must have an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN issued no later than the filing date of your 2024 tax return (including extensions). For more information, see Appendix 8812 (Form 1040) and the instructions for filing.

You may be eligible for a tax credit of up to $16,810 for qualified adoption expenses for a qualified child.In the case of adopting a child with special needs, the credit may be claimed regardless of whether you have incurred the qualified expenses.To claim the credit for adoption expenses, file Form 8839 along with Form 1040 or 1040-SR.

To qualify for EIC, you must be earning income from working for someone or from running or owning a business or farm and meet the basic rules. In addition, you must either meet the additional rules for workers who do not have a child who meets the established criteria or have a child who meets all the established criteria for children. The EIC reduces the amount of tax owed and can help you get a refund. For more information, please refer to IRS.gov/EIC. If you (or, in the case of a joint tax return, your spouse) have not been issued an SSN before the filing date or the filing date of your 2024 tax return, or if you have a spouse who is a U.S. citizen or has not been a U.S. citizen or has not been a U.S. citizen before the filing date of your 2024 tax return, you may apply for an EIC supplement without having your spouse's SSN or Social Security number removed from your Social Security number, or you may claim a Social Security benefit withdrawal with your spouse's SSN or Social Security withdrawal from your EIC, or if your spouse is a U.S.S. citizen or has not been a U.S.S. citizen before the filing date of your 2024 tax return, or if you are a U.S.S. citizen or have a spouse who is a U.S.S. citizen or has not with a Social Security number removed from your SSN or a prior to the filing date of your 2024 tax return, or if your first filing date of your first filing date, or if your spouse is a U.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.S.
These credits are only allowed if you actually earn income from your business in the U.S. You may be eligible for some of the following credits.

If you have income from a foreign source that is actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States, you may claim a refund of any income taxes paid or accrued in any foreign state or U.S. territory on that income. If you do not have income from a foreign source that is actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States, you may not claim a refund of U.S. tax on taxes paid or accrued in a foreign state or U.S. territory. You may not receive a credit for paying taxes levied by a foreign state or U.S. territory on your income from a source in the United States if those taxes were accrued only because you are a citizen or resident of a foreign state or territory. If you file a return for income tax, you will need to provide the additional information you have requested, as you will usually find on your tax return (see Form 111-5614).

You may be eligible for this credit if you pay someone to care for your dependent child under the age of 13 who meets the specified criteria, or for your dependent disabled child or disabled spouse so that you can work or look for work. For definitions of these terms, see Publication No. 503 (English). Married nonresident aliens may qualify for this credit only if they choose to file a joint return with a U.S. citizen or resident spouse as described in the "How to Choose" subchapter in Chapter 1, or if they are married persons living apart (see Publication No. 503 (English) Joint Return Test). For your child's total combined income and for your dependent disabled child's total income and for your dependent, see the Income Tax Information for the tax year, and for any income you have received for the tax year, see the Income Tax Credit for the tax year.

If you do not have an SSN (or ITIN) issued before or on the 2024 tax filing deadline (including renewals) or before that date, you cannot claim a tax credit for the child on either the original or the amended return. If your child did not have a valid SSN for employment issued before or on the 2024 tax filing deadline (including renewals), you cannot claim a tax credit for that child, but you can claim a credit for other dependents for that child.

A dependent who does not qualify for a child tax credit may nonetheless qualify for a credit for other dependents. This is a nonrefundable tax credit of $500 per eligible person. A dependent who qualifies must be a U.S. citizen, a resident of an unincorporated territory (such as American Samoa), or a resident alien. See the instructions for Form 1040-NR (English) To qualify for a credit for other dependents, your dependent must have an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN issued no later than the 2024 tax filing deadline (including extensions). Only nonresident aliens who are residents of unincorporated territories; residents of Canada, Mexico, or South Korea; or students from India and India who are eligible for the benefit of the Income Tax Credit and are eligible for other benefits under the Income Tax Credit Agreement can qualify for the benefit. 212)

To get a credit for adoption, file Form 8839 with your Form 1040-NR. Married nonresident aliens may qualify for a credit only if they choose to file jointly with a U.S. citizen spouse or a resident spouse as described in the "Nonresident Spouse Regarded as a Resident" section of Chapter 1, or if the spouses qualify as defined marriage partners (see section L and the Married U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services Instruction for Filing a U.S. Citizen's U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services Income Tax Return in the section "Civil Residence").
If you paid alternative minimum tax in the previous year, use Form 8801 and the instructions for it to find out whether you are entitled to this credit.

If you or your spouse did not have an SSN issued before or on the date of the 2024 tax return (including the extension), you may not claim either the EIC on the original return or the 2024 amended return. However, if you are married and choose to file a joint return with a U.S. citizen spouse or a resident spouse as described in the "Nonresident Spouse Regarded as a Resident" section of Chapter 1, you may be eligible for the credit. If you or your spouse did not have an SSN issued before or on the date of the 2024 tax return (including the extension), you may not claim either the EIC on the original return or the 2024 amended return.

You can claim that the tax withheld during the year goes to your U.S. tax bill. Specify the relevant information in lines 25a through 25g of Form 1040-NR. The withheld tax reduces the amount of any tax you owe on Form 1040-NR.

Any federal income tax withheld from your pay during the tax year when you were a nonresident alien is allowed as a payment on your U.S. income tax liability for that year. You may claim that the tax withheld during the year goes to your U.S. tax payment regardless of whether you were engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States during the year and whether the pay (or any other income) was related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States.

Your employer is responsible for withholding 0.9% (0.009) of the Medicare surtax from wages or Railway Transportation Employee Retirement Allowance (RRTA) payments in excess of US$200,000 in 2024. If you do not have a Medicare surtax liability, you may claim a deduction for any withheld surtax from the Medicare surtax on your total tax liability on your tax return by completing Form 8959.

You can use as payment any tax withheld until you make a payment on an investment or on other fixed or determinable annual or periodic income paid to you. Fixed or determinable income includes interest, dividends, rent and royalties that you do not actually call linked income. Wages or salaries may be fixed or determinable income to you, and are usually subject to withholding as described above. Taxes on fixed or determinable income are withheld at a rate of 30% or at a lower contractual rate.

If you are a foreign partner in a partnership, the partnership will withhold tax on your share of the effectively connected taxable income from the partnership. The partnership will provide you with a report on Form 8805 indicating the withheld tax. The partnership whose shares are bought and sold on the stock exchange may withhold taxes from the amount of the income distribution on your effectively connected income. In this case, the partnership will provide you with a report on Form 1042-S. Depending on the circumstances, indicate the withheld tax as a payment either on line 25e or line 25g of Form 1040-NR.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner in a U.S. or foreign partnership that engages (or is deemed to engage) in a professional or commercial activity in the United States, and you directly or indirectly dispose of that interest to receive profits, then for transfers occurring after 2017, the recipient generally withholds and pays to the IRS on your behalf a tax equal to 10% of the amount realized on the sale. The rules for withholding and payments in excess of this amount are similar to the rules for the sale of shares in U.S. real estate. You will receive Form 8288-A, reflecting the withheld amount, which you can then claim on line 25f of your Form 1040-NR as the tax for the profits you are required to report. You may be required to provide certain information to the recipient to withhold and pay to the IRS on your behalf a tax equal to 10% of the amount realized on the sale. If the recipient is not in compliance with the IRS regulations, the IRS will require you to file a withholding and payment notice in accordance with Section 1446 (IRS) of the IRS's 2020 Tax Retention and Income Taxation Rules (FIRS.F.46), which is published in IRS Section 1446 (IRS.46f.

You can use as payment any tax withheld in connection with the surrender of a U.S. interest in a U.S. property (or income deemed to have been received as a result of the surrender of a U.S. interest in a U.S. property). See the section "Profits or Losses from Real Property" in Chapter 4. The buyer will provide you with a statement of the amount withheld on Form 8288-A. Please provide the information about the tax withheld as payment on line 25f of Form 1040-NR.

If you are a nonresident alien who is a valid resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you are generally taxed in the same way as resident aliens. You should file Form 1040 or 1040-SR and provide information on all income from sources both in the United States and outside. However, you may exclude income described in the following paragraphs. However, for tax purposes other than income reporting, you will be treated as a nonresident alien.

If you are a valid resident of Puerto Rico for the entire year, you may exclude from gross income all income from sources in Puerto Rico (except amounts for services rendered as an employee of the United States or any of its agencies). If you report income for a calendar year and you do not have a salary subject to withholding in 2024, file the return and pay the tax by June 16, 2025. You must also make your first estimated tax payment for 2025 by June 16, 2024.

You must calculate your income and file your tax return based on an annual reporting period called a tax year. If you have not previously established a fiscal year, your tax year will be the calendar year. Calendar year  is the 12 consecutive months ending on December 31. If you have previously established a standard fiscal year (12 consecutive months ending on the last day of the month except December, or 52-53 weekly years) and you consider yourself a U.S. resident during any calendar year, you will be considered a U.S. resident during any part of the fiscal year falling on that calendar year.

A taxpayer identification number (TIN) must be listed on tax returns, statements, and other tax documents. For individuals, it is a social security number (SSN). If you do not have an SSN and are not eligible for one, you must apply for an individual taxpayer identification number (ITIN). An employer identification number (EIN) is required if you are engaged in a professional or commercial activity as an individual entrepreneur and have employees or a qualifying retirement plan. You must provide a taxpayer identification number (TIN) if you are... an alien whose income is directly related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States during any time during the year; any alien who has an office or activity in the United States during any time during the year; a spouse who is a U.S. resident, or any other person who is treated as a resident of the United States, or who is treated as a resident of the United States, or any other person who is treated as a resident of the United States, or who is treated as a resident of the United States, or who is filing a tax return with a single tax identification number (UIN number); or any other tax identification number that is not required by law).

Some ITINs need to be updated. If you did not use your ITIN when filing your federal tax return at least once for the 2021, 2022 or 2023 tax year, it expires on December 31, 2024, and if you need to file a federal tax return for 2024, the ITIN needs to be updated. You do not need to update your ITIN if you do not need to file a federal tax return. To update your ITIN, see Form W-7 and the instructions for it at IRS.gov/FormW7. For more information, see IRS.gov/ITIN. ITINs issued before 2013 have expired, and if you need to file a federal tax return for 2024, they need to be renewed. If you previously applied for a renewal and it was approved, you do not need to renew it again if you did not use your ITIN at least once in the 2021 or 2023 tax year.

The amount of your tax depends on your tax status.Your tax status is important for determining whether you can deduct and add certain amounts.The rules for determining your tax status differ for resident and non-resident aliens.

If your spouse died in 2022 or 2023 and you did not remarry before the end of 2024, you may be eligible to file as a widow or widower eligible for tax benefits and use the joint filing tax rates.This only applies if you were able to file a joint tax return with your spouse for the year of your spouse's death.For details on filing status of a widow or widower eligible for tax benefits, see the sub-section Widow or widower eligible for tax benefits in the section Tax status in the instructions for Form 1040 for 2024.

Nonresident aliens married to non-U.S. citizens or residents are generally required to use the Taxation Grid or the Taxation Work Sheet for married individuals filing separately when determining income tax on income actually related to a U.S. professional or commercial activity.

However, you may file as a single person if you have lived separately from your spouse for the past 6 months and you are a married Canadian, Mexican, or South Korean resident or a married non-resident of a non-incorporated territory. See the instructions for Form 1040-NR to see if you are eligible. The definition of a non-incorporated resident is given below in this section.

If your spouse died in 2022 or 2023 and you did not marry before the end of 2024, you may be eligible to file as a widow with a right to tax benefits and to use the tax rates of joint filers. For details of the tax status of a widow with a right to tax benefits, see the section entitled to tax benefits in the section entitled to tax benefits and the instructions for Form 1040-NR (English) for 2024.

An estate or a nonresident alien's trust using Form 1040-NR must use the W-tax rate schedule in the instructions for Form 1040-NR when determining income tax on income actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States.

You must report on every item of income that is taxable under the provisions of the law in Chapters 2, 3, and 4. For resident aliens, this includes income from sources both in and outside the United States. For nonresident aliens, this includes both income that is actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States (assuming a differentiated tax rate) and income from sources in the United States that are not actually related (subject to a flat tax rate of 30% or a lower tax rate under a double taxation treaty).

You can claim deductions to calculate your taxable income directly related to your activities in the United States (ECTI). Generally, you cannot claim deductions related to income not related to your business activities in the United States. The exception is certain itemized deductions discussed below. You can only claim deductions to the extent that they relate to income related to your business activities in the United States.

If you have income that is actually related to your professional or business activities in the United States, you may deduct up to 20% of your qualifying income from your qualifying professional or business activities, plus 20% of your qualifying dividend income from your qualifying REIT and qualifying partnership with a PTC (PTC) that is not a member of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

If you contributed to a Traditional IRA for 2024, you can claim this deduction on your tax return, but you must have taxable compensation actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the U.S. Form 5498 must be sent to you by June 2, 2025, and it will list all contributions to your Traditional IRA for 2024. If you were insured under a retirement plan (qualifying pension, profit sharing (including 401k), annuity, SIMPLE, SEPLE, etc.), employed or self-employed, your IRA deduction may be reduced or waived.

Do not include in your income the cost of moving and storage services provided by the state for moving to a new permanent place of employment, or the amount of money received as a move allowance, temporary accommodation expenses, temporary accommodation allowance or tax deductions for housing.

You must include in your income all actual interest-related income that you receive or that is credited to your account during the year. Do not deduct it by any penalty that you must pay for early withdrawal of funds from a savings account. However, if the interest income is actually related to your professional or commercial activities in the United States during the year, you may deduct in line 18 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040) the amount of the penalty for early withdrawal charged by the banking institution.

If you do not provide the SSN, ITIN or the individual taxpayer identification number (ATIN) of the dependent child in the 'Dependents' section of your tax return, or if you provide the wrong number, some tax benefits may not be available.

If you are a resident alien, your child or a qualifying relative may be a legal dependent. Five tests are required to qualify a child. Four tests are required to qualify a person as a qualifying relative. For more information, see the instructions for Form 1040. If you do not provide the SSN, ITIN, or ATIN of a dependent in the "Dependents" section of your tax return, or if you provide the wrong number, some tax benefits may not be available. See the "Identification Number" section above.

You are considered to have a dual tax year if you were both a resident alien and a nonresident alien in the same year. Dual taxation does not apply to your citizenship; it only applies to your status as a resident in the United States for tax purposes. When determining your U.S. income tax liability for a dual tax year, different rules apply for the part of the year during which you are a resident of the United States and the part of the year during which you are a nonresident. The most common dual taxation years are the years of arrival and departure.

If your tax year does not coincide with a calendar year, you must file the tax return no later than the 15th day of the fourth month following your tax year. In both cases, you must file the tax return at the address designated for aliens with dual status during one tax year, as indicated on the instruction sheet for Form 1040. If you are a nonresident and you report your income on the last day of your tax year and you report your income on the last day of your tax year, you must file the tax return no later than the 15th day of both months of the calendar year following your tax year (see the TIP advice below). If your tax year does not coincide with a calendar year, you must file the tax return no later than the 15th day of the fourth month following your tax year. If you are a resident of the United States and you are not filing your income tax return on the last day of your tax year, you must file your tax return on the fourth day of both months of the calendar year following your tax year. If you are filing your income tax return on the last day of the fourth month following your tax year, you must file it at the IRS Box, at the NC-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130-130

If you are not a U.S. resident, you may file a tax return based on the annual reporting period called a "tax year". If you have not previously established a fiscal year, your tax year is the calendar year. A calendar year is 12 consecutive months ending on December 31. If you have previously established a regular fiscal year (12 consecutive months ending on the last day of a month other than December, or a 52-53-week year), and you are a U.S. resident during any calendar year, you will be considered a U.S. resident during any part of your fiscal year that falls within that calendar year.

For the part of the year when you are a resident alien, you are taxed on income from all sources. Income from sources outside the United States is taxed if you receive it while you are a resident alien. Income is taxed even if you earned it while you were a nonresident alien, or if you became a nonresident alien after you received it and before the end of the year. For the part of the year when you are a nonresident alien, you are taxed on income from sources in the United States and on certain income from foreign sources that are treated as actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States. However, the rules for accounting for income from foreign sources as actually related are discussed in the "Foreign income" agreement in Chapter 4 of the United States Tax Code, and the income from sources outside the United States is taxed even if you earned it as a nonresident alien and received it after the end of the year.
The following restrictions apply if you filed your tax return for the tax year with a double tax status.
You can't use the standard deduction allowed on a Form 1040 or a Form 1040-SR, but you can specify any itemized deductions that are allowed.

As a dual-status taxpayer, you can list a dependent on your tax return. Generally, a dependent is a qualifying child or qualifying relative. You may be eligible for additional deductions and credits if you have a qualifying dependent. For more information, see the Form 1040 instructions or the Form 1040-NR instructions. If you were a non-incorporated resident or lived in Canada or Mexico, you can list a dependent under the same conditions as U.S. citizens. If you are a resident of South Korea or India, see Chapter 5.

If you are filing your U.S. tax return for a dual-status year, you are subject to different rules for the part of the year in which you are a resident and the part of the year in which you are a non-resident.

All income during your residency and all income that is actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States during your non-residency, after allowable deductions, is taxed at the same rates that apply to U.S. citizens and residents.Even income that is not related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States during your non-residency is taxed at a flat rate of 30% or the lower of the contractual rate.You cannot deduct any income from this income.

During the part of the year in which you are a nonresident alien, 85% of any U.S. Social Security payments (and the equivalent portion of Tier 1 Railroad employee pension payments) that you receive are taxed at a flat rate of 30% unless you are exempt or taxed at a lower contractual rate. (See the "30% tax" section in Chapter 4) During the part of the year in which you are a nonresident alien, part of the Social Security payments and the equivalent portion of the Tier 1 Railroad employee payments will be taxed at a differentiated rate if your gross adjusted income plus the equivalent portion of those payments exceeds a certain base amount. Therefore, use the RSA-1042 to calculate the correct amount of payments from the Railroad Social Security Fund and the equivalent portion of payments from the Social Security Fund for your nonresident alien during the year in which you receive these payments. If you are a nonresident alien, you will need to file a Form RR-1042 with the IRS and submit the correct information for your railroad employee pension payments to the IRS for the entire year to determine the amount of the payments and the amount of the payments.
